Inspector.
Received a letter yesterday from the Civil Service Commission notifying me to present myself for oral examination here Wed Oct 15th and also the following paragraph:

"This is not to be misinterpreted as 'the offer of a position.' It is merely a qualifying test to determine your fitness for employment of the above mentioned nature."

Provided that I am the only applicant for this position, have not the least hesitation in attending and answering any well questions relative to the work involved but if I have to compete with some ordinary carpenter or other laymen of the building trades, I would consider this action as uncalled for and a challenge to my ability and standing in my profession having been in practice now about 25 yrs.

I am writing to you personally as one man to another for your advice and how I should settle this matter.

Dear Sirs:

We have been advised by our source of supply that the Doric Water Heater specified by the Department of Indian Affairs, for the new Shingwauk Home has been discontinued, and also that if this type of heater were still manufactured it would not be the proper type to carry 85# water pressure.

The only Boiler which will do this work is a #4 Pendell Boiler which will cost you $230.00 f.o.b. Toronto.

We would ask you to take this matter up with the Department and find out from them if it will be satisfactory for us to supply a Pendell Boiler at the extra price.

We trust that you will give this your immediate attention, in order that no delay will be caused in having the material placed on the Job.

Yours very truly,

LYONS FUEL HDWE. & SUPPLIES LTD.

Dear Sir:

We are mailing you today under separate cover a set of floor plans showing proposed layout of electric lighting in the new Shingwauk Home this city.

We have taken this matter up with the local Hydro Inspector and he has approved our proposed layout. He has suggested however that he would prefer to have an extra pony panel installed on main switch board in bakery, this panel not to have separate switches on circuits. He suggests that basement circuits #9 - 10 - 22 - and 24 and ground floor circuits #6 - 7 and 8 be fed from this panel. These circuits are all controlled from wall switches in various rooms and some confusion may arise should someone switch off these circuits in error if they are fed from panels as shown on plan. He also points out that if these circuits are fed from a panel mounted at service panel the runs would be shorter and therefore less possibility of drop in voltage due to line loss.

Should the suggestions of Inspector as outlined above meet with your approval we would be prepared to make this change at no extra charge.

We would appreciate an early reply in this matter as work is progressing rapidly on building and we would like to get cabinets for panels on order so that we may have them on hand to build in walls as walls go up.

Yours very truly,

O. C. CARNEY & CO.,

[Signature]

Mgr.

Re Shingwauk Home Building.

Dear Sir,

Just a few lines to inform you that I intend to go to North Bay on business on the 21st of this month and expect that I might be away possibly two or three days, consequently I thought that I had better write and let you know as you told me that you expected to be here in the Sault in a month that would be about the 15th of this month and I would like to be here when you come.

The job is progressing quite favourably we have nearly all the window frames set in the basement and started to build partitions yesterday, while today we started a gang of men on the outside walls.

Hoping to hear from you in the near future I beg to remain,

Very truly yours,

J. J. Fitzpatrick.

Dear Sir:

In your specifications of the Shingwauk Home, being built here, you call for bronze face sash pulleys.

We have tried all over Canada and the United States to get same, but apparently they do not keep them in stock but can make them up for us in a months time, which is too late for the job as the contractor will be needing them before that time.

We have taken the matter up with Mr. T. Wilks, who, we understand, is in charge here at present, and have shown him the sash pulleys we have here. He believes that they would be alright but advised us to write you and explain the situation.

Kindly let us know as soon as possible what to do about this matter.

Yours truly,

Hesson Lumber Co. Limited.

WINNIPEG, MAN., October 10th, 1934.

The Secretary,
The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Our Commission has been requested by the Rev. C. F. Hives, Principal of our Shingwauk Home to arrange for the laying of a corner stone in connection with the new school building now being erected, and this request was favourably considered by the Commission at a meeting held here yesterday. In this connection I was asked to submit the matter to you for your approval, and for your help in carrying the ceremony through. The stone would not be expensive, and the ceremony should not delay the work for possibly more than one hour. If your Department approves the undertaking, His Grace, Archbishop Thorneleoe, now living retired in Sault Ste. Marie, but who has had a very long connection with the old building soon to be superseded by the new structure, will be asked to officially lay the stone. Should he be unwell or otherwise unable to be present at the time, his place would be taken by the Rt. Rev. Dr. Rockesborough Smith, Lord Bishop of Algoma.

As I understand the building is going up rapidly, it will be appreciated if you can let me have your reply with the least delay possible.

Your obedient servant,

Field Secretary M.S.C.C.

Progress report week ending Oct. 20, 1934.

New Shingwauk Home, Sault-Ste-Marie, Ontario.

Concrete work.
All walls and foundation work complete except steps to front entrance; carpenters now putting up forms for same.
Cement plaster facing on exterior walls; about 90% done.

Brick Masonry.
All main walls and cross walls; basement to ground floor level complete except 4" linings to stairs halls; kitchen and scvery.

Stonework.
Silt course over basement windows all complete in main building.

Steelwork.
Basement Cols and beams erected in main building; this means corridor steel in dining room and 24" beams in recreation rooms.

Electrician.
Placing in wall switch and plug outlets as work proceeds.

Plumbing.
Excavating and laying cast iron storm water drains boiler room to end of corridor near dining room.

Materials.
Materials are being delivered in good order to allow proper progress of the work.

Inspector.
Dear Sir:

The recent storms have made havoc of parts of the roof of our building, so that the rain comes in freely. The laundry, in particular, is in very bad shape, and requires rubberoid roofing. In parts of the main building the shingles have blown off, and should be replaced. Today has been wet, and so I have noticed the leakages. I estimate that it will cost fifty dollars to buy material. We can do the work ourselves.

Will you kindly place this matter before the department, asking them if they will kindly sanction the expenditure of fifty dollars for this work.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Principal.

Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Enclosed herewith, please find account from Flockhart Bros. for the amount of $145.73 representing expenses for repairs of furnace of chapel. I may say that this chapel has always been used by our pupils, and is not maintained by any other congregation. A few weeks ago, I had to inspect the furnace, and found that unless immediate repairs were made there would be great danger of the chapel being destroyed by fire. I therefore got in a man, who said the furnace was useless, and that a new fire box etc., would be required. There was nothing for it but to have it done. The cost is more than I reckoned on, but the work has been well done.

I am forwarding the account to you with the hope that you will pay it. Or if the department cannot pay it all, would they kindly consider paying part, and I will see if I can get the balance from my staff.

As I have said above, the chapel has always been used entirely by the pupils of Shingwauk Home, and I don't think the department has ever before been asked to stand the expenses of repairs. I managed, soon after I came to Shingwauk to collect about $500.00 for a new roof, but I doubt if I could collect the amount required to meet the enclosed bill.

Will you kindly give this matter your best consideration.

Your obedient servant,

As suggested in our conversation yesterday I am submitting prices on conduit installed for telephone also for power service for new Shingwauk Home.

The telephone company would run their line below the power and lighting lines on the same poles.

Mr. Hives is of the opinion that there should be outlets for two telephones. One in floor about the center of his office and the other on west wall of staff parlor near door. The telephone company will run wires to the above points but owing to the type of construction think their lines should be run in conduit. If this is done they say the conduit will have to be installed and supplied by the owner. We would be willing to supply and install conduit and fittings as required by the Telephone Co. for the two (2) phone outlets for TWENTY TWO DOLLARS & FORTY CENTS, ($22.40).

The heating contractor is anxious to get motors on heating system connected up so that boilers may be used for temporary heating of building. We have already installed a 1" conduit built in masonry beside lighting service to provide for power service. We would suggest that a 3 pole, 250 volt, 100 amp. switch be installed on board beside lighting service as a power main switch. From this 100 amp. switch wire to a top feed three phase meter below switch, and from meter back into switch box. From 100 amp. box run metal wiring trough and #6 cables to feed switches for motors as required. See enclosed sketch.

Separate switches feeding from main cables in trough are required for each motor fed from power service.

Progress report, week ending Dec. 22nd, 1934.

New Shingwauk Home, Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.

Concrete work.
All reinforced concrete slab floors have been poured from Ground floor to attic also front interior steps entrance to ground floor.

Brickwork.
All interior partitions are built in from attic down to 1st floor, and approx. 80% of partitions are built in on ground floor.

Carpenter work.
All wood bucks are in down to G. floor, and form work completed to stair landings and beams to both stairways, putting up corner beads to window openings etc.

Metal Lath.
Metal lath work complete on 1st and 2nd floors and ceilings of 1st and 2nd floors approx. 50% complete, beams and columns in centre portion of building are furred and lathed also columns on 2nd floor.

Painter.
All exterior work such as eaves cornice, dormers etc., have received 3 coats of paint. Spire about 50% done. Assembly hall ceiling has been stained and about one third shellacked.

Roofs.
Nothing further has been done on deck roofs since last report.

Heating.
Run outs to radiators have been put in on 1st and 2nd floors, and most of this work has been done on ground floor, including to assembly hall. Smoke stacks and breeching completed to boilers, heater etc., in boiler room.

Plumbing.
All water mains and branches to the several plumbing fixtures have been laid throughout the building, except to laundry, and hot water pipes to fixtures above ground floor. Roughing in has been completed to all fixtures and all vent stacks through roofs and flashed.

Tinsmiths.
All eaves trough and rain conductors are completed. Spire approx. 80% done, and portion of flat roofs over stairs.

Electrician.
Pipe work complete on 2nd floor and centre portions of ground and first floors, including distribution panels in place, now working on wings of these floors. Some bell work has been done on 1st and 2nd floors and alarm systems to fire exit doors on these floors. City light dept. have both power and light services in.

Dear Mr Orr:

Since your visit to us, my wife and I have been living pretty much in our new residence. My wife, in particular, seems to get quite a kick out of it. She has tried to draw it, and has got it pretty well furnished. It is surprising how cheaply one can richly furnish a house by drawing on the Bank of Imagination. The only thing she seems to see wrong is that it appears to be just a little cramped. I really think if the length was given two feet and two feet on to the width, it would be very much better. What do you think of this? I don't want to leave it until it is finished before speaking, and I don't want to spoil anything by being selfish. But we have other people to think of beside ourselves, and it seems to me we find it that way more than we did in the north.

Things are progressing very well in the building. It is greatly admired by all who see it, and quite a lot of people come down to look it over.

Kindest regards, and don't think we are ungrateful. We are extremely conscious of having received a lot.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sir:

Having been awarded the contract by Mr. J. J. Fitzpatrick, for the terrazzo work of the Shingwauk Home, Sault Ste. Marie, Ont., we desire the following information. What color or colors of marble aggregates with the percentage of each color to be used in the terrazzo floors.

Your specification calls for a mix of one to four of Silica Sand and 40% crushed marble. The standard specifications demand that 80% to 90% marble shall show in the surface of the finished floor and this result could not be obtained with the above specification.

We take the liberty of submitting the specification generally used on high class work, for your approval, which we propose to use.

On the concrete slab or under floor lay and tamp one to four cement and sand concrete bed within 3/4" of the finished surface. In this bed insert the brass stops as specified. When this concrete underbed has sufficiently set to permit rolling, cover the floor with a wet mix consisting of two bags marble chips to one bag Portland Cement, approximately 3/4" thick; roll in two directions with a heavy roller forcing the surplus cement grout to the surface and remove with a broom; when the surplus cement is all extracted trowel off. When the floor has hardened sufficiently to permit grinding, grind with floor machines using #40 grit carborundum stones until 80% or 90% of the marble aggregate shows in the finished surface. Grout well with neat cement rubbing same into any voids and let the grout set thoroughly then finish grinding with #60, or finer stones if necessary, to the required fine finish.
January 24th, 1935.

Please be kind enough to advise us if you approve of this method which, as we said before, is the recognized specification for the terrazzo work.

Yours very truly,

Memorandum

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

With reference to the Memorandum to Council asking for authority for the expenditure of an additional sum of $4,000 in connection with the new Shingwauk Indian Residential School, this amount is estimated to be required to cover the cost of additional work not included in the contract, and the purchase of fuel for the heating of the building during construction.

The specifications provide that the Department will supply the fuel needed to heat the building during construction, the Contractor to supply the heating apparatus and attendance. The cost of the fuel for the season will amount to approximately $1,200, depending of course on weather conditions.

Several minor changes in the interior of the building were asked for by the Reverend Principal during the course of construction. The cost of these changes together with the connecting up to the City water supply system and the existing sewage disposal system, the installing of a new power line from the City main to the school and other incidental expenses will cost approximately $2,800.00.

Dear Mr Orr:

As you know, the 21st of June was the date, more or less set for the opening of the new school. I have been wondering if this date will be convenient, or if you would rather it were postponed until the Fall, say September. Gentlemen:

Received your letter of August 6th, saying our offer was accepted on the Shingwauk School provided we could install the fixtures by September 1st. It has been so long since we submitted our prices that we thought someone else had the job, and your letter was a great surprise to us.

We cannot complete the job by Sept. 1. Mr. Hives from the school will be in Ottawa by the time you receive this letter, and he will explain the situation much better than we can by letter. We will have to wait until we hear from Mr. Hives or yourselves.

We are ready to start the job any time, and will rush work as fast as possible. We can do any part of the work first that Mr. Hives might want done.

We hope this is satisfactory, and thank you for favouring us with the order.

Yours truly,

SPECIFICATIONS for the demolishing of the old Shingwauk Indian Residential School at Sault Ste Marie, Ontario.

Tenders will be received up to noon of the 23rd day of December, 1935, for the demolishing of the building above mentioned.

In the demolishing of this building it is the intention that that portion occupied as a Principal's residence be left standing, and the Contractor will be required to take all care and precautions that no damage is done to this portion of the building.

Tenders shall be enclosed in a sealed envelope addressed to the Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, and clearly marked on the envelope,—

"TENDER FOR DEMOLITION OF THE OLD SHINGWAUK INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL AT SAULT STE MARIE, ONT."

Before submitting a tender the bidders shall visit the building, examine for themselves the present condition, and ascertain for themselves the nature of the work, and fully inform themselves as to all existing conditions, especially as to risks, accidents, damage, etc., which might result from the above mentioned work.

The firms submitting a tender shall be required to provide and send in with tender a marked cheque for FIVE HUNDRED DOLLARS ($500.00) accepted by a chartered bank of Canada, and made payable to the Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs. This cheque will be held as deposit security until the satisfactory completion of the contract.

Unsuccessful tenderers shall have their cheques returned as soon as an offer has been accepted.

The Contractor shall state in his tender the time required for the completion of the work. The work shall commence immediately upon being notified of the acceptance of the tender, and shall proceed without delay, and shall be completed within the time specified.

The Contractor shall be responsible for any injury to nonwhite pupils, staff of the school and the general public, and shall take whatever measures are necessary to safeguard against injuries to persons or property. He shall be responsible for any and all damage done to adjoining buildings, where any walls are in a dangerous condition they shall be shored before the roof is taken off to prevent same from falling, and props shall be placed under the ceiling joists where there is danger of the brickwork falling. The outside walls of the entire building shall be demolished in such a way as to maintain a uniform height. All walls shall be taken down to at least 18 inches below grade level, and old basement must not be filled higher than will allow for 18 inches of earth over top of same.
Sheet 2.

The Contractor will not be expected to provide this earth filling, but will leave the old foundation graded level ready to receive top dressing.

Chimneys and air shafts also hot air flues shall be taken down as the demolishing of the walls proceeds on a corresponding level, and not allowed to stand with the idea of pulling them over afterwards.

The Contractor shall have all electric light wires disconnected before proceeding with the work, and all loose wires hanging outside that might be dangerous shall be removed.

Before removing the plumbing fixtures the Contractor shall have the water disconnected from the building and when the fixtures are removed carefully seal up the ends of water pipes.

Materials must not be allowed to accumulate on floors. No lumber or shingles shall be used to fill in old basement.

All materials in the buildings, together with all attached fixtures and fittings now in the building shall become the property of the Contractor, and shall be removed from the premises.

All stone and brick in the existing building may be used to fill in the basement, providing the filling does not reach higher than 18 inches below finished grade, as above specified. All material over and above and above this amount must be removed from the premises.

If the Contractor so desires he may remove all the stone and brick in the building from the premises.

Dear Mr Orr:

You asked me to let you know how the water is working since the change was made. The enclosed chart will speak for itself. It is not very satisfactory, and I am afraid we shall have trouble with it until a larger main pipe is laid. I have had one of the city water men down, and he also is convinced that we have not the volume in the three inch main that we should have to maintain a steady pressure.

I went to see the Superintendent of the City Water Commission, and he is very anxious to see a six inch water main laid down to us. This would cost quite a sum of money. The pipe itself would cost one dollar per foot, and the distance is nearly five thousand feet. Then there would be the digging and the back filling. I am quite sure the city would not stand all the expense, but do you suppose the Department would help them. Mr Gormell is anxious to do something in the matter, and would like to know if they could co-operate with us over the matter.

Another thing, the present pipe has been in for over thirty years, and it is not a galvanized iron pipe, and so I think there is great danger of it bursting, and giving us trouble that way. I have spoken to men who are more or less expert in that matter, and they feel there is great danger of this.

I am enclosing accounts we went through while you were here.

Dear Mr Orr:

There are two things I would like to bring to your notice. One is the laundry business. The fan has been installed, but it is of little or no value, and the steam continues to be terrible. I really believe if a galvanized hood was made to fit over above the washer, and to discharge outside with the fan on the end of it, it would answer the purpose, and do what we require in ridding the place of the steam. I am afraid of it at the present time. The girls get very wet, and then go out into the cold, and it is not good for them.

The other thing concerns the sunroom. The steam pipes connected with the radiators there, as well as the returns are in between the ceiling and the floor, and as you know, the entrance is open. These pipes got frozen up during the last cold weather, and the radiators were burst. I have had them disconnected, and plugged, so they are not now in commission. If it is your wish that they should be put into order again, and I think they should, the pipes should be changed from between the ceiling and the floor, and brought above the floor. In that way, I do not think they will give any trouble.

Will you please let me know what you wish in these matters.

Our weather has been very cold. The longest cold snap I have experienced here, but the building has been wonderful.

Yours faithfully,

You will note that the shower room is on the other side of the wall. I suppose you would not consider putting the tank in there.

I have just mailed a picture of Shingwauk ancient and modern to you. I think it is a very interesting picture, and shows fairly clearly what the place can be developed into, after the old building is removed. It really is too bad we could not pull down that old barn right away, and yet we cannot until a new one is built. You will try and get us a new barn in your supplementary, also a root cellar and garage?

I called at the Canadian Laundry Machinery Co., and they said they thought the only way to do away with the steam trouble is to increase the radiation. This can be done quite simply. Will you please let me know if I am to have this work done.

Our sickness seems to be disappearing, and I sincerely hope we shall soon be clear.

The Bank of Montreal manager called me up this morning asking if the Imperial Radio Co. had been paid. I guess they are owing them money.

Dear Mr Orr:

I am enclosing several accounts to you for payment. I am afraid you will think there is no end to them, though I hope they are tailing off, and just as soon as we get the high pressure water problem adjusted, I think things will be alright. As it is, I am afraid of getting high blood pressure, for it is kind of nerve racking not knowing just when something is going to break loose. Today, I have been putting in a new gasket in the steam cooling coil. I thought I would rather do it myself than get the plumber, for I really don't think he knows much. Anyway I got it done, and it is tight, and that's more than he has done.

There are two accounts pinned together, one for $53.84 from Soo Lumber, and one for $20.69 from Gochrane Hardware. These are for greenhouse material. Dear Sir,-

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 8th instant, enclosing letter received from the Principal of the Shingwauk Home, requesting an expenditure of, approximately, $250 for a new fence.

As you are aware, the Department has endeavoured to treat this school very generously during the past year and, as our funds are limited, the Shingwauk Home will have to wait for further improvements.

Dear Mr Orr:

The work is progressing very well. They have the footings in today, and they reckon on running the basement walls on Wednesday next. Dear Mr Orr:

I had a look-see at these wonderful plans of the new school at Moosonee, and really must say, I don't like them. Whoever heard of a girl's playroom in the attic, alongside of the sewingroom. It will be a terrible business supervising girls way up there, and then, all the clothing has to be carried from the laundry up to the sewingroom in the attic. I understand also that there is a low partition between the little girl's and little boys' dormitory. I think they are looking for trouble. I may be wrong, but the plans don't attract me at all.

Canen Gould informs me that they are deciding to go ahead with them.

Kindest regards,

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

P.S. Don't you think you could get the plans and have them looked over, and if necessary criticise them and if proper, condemn them. The Department has it in its power to do so.
Dear Mr Orr:

In reply to your letter of the 14th inst., I am sorry that the Ochranes Dunlop Co., account is not satisfactory, but I tried to get a boiler at the West End Hardware, and they had not anything of that nature in. I was anxious to get into the house, and perhaps hurried a little more than I should have done, and got it from a firm that had it in stock. In regard to the automatic control, which was $25 extra, an ordinary switch control was specified, but this should have been installed before the plastering was done so that it could have been operated in the kitchen, as you knew, although it is the Principal's residence, it has always been my policy to try and work in as many of the girls as possible in the way of giving them a training as domestics. I have heard that switch controls have been left on by different people here in the city, and that ruined tanks have been the results. By having the automatic control, I felt that this danger would be eliminated, even though one of the girls did happen to be left in charge. I am enclosing a statement from the Ochranes Dunlop Co., with the charge for automatic control taken off. If it is your wish that the enclosed should replace the one formerly sent, I shall be glad to look after the automatic, for I feel very much safer with it.

I have made several inquiries regarding the electric range, and find that the oven control is standard equipment in ranges with even one side.

I hope this explains matters sufficiently.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Dear Sir:

We have just finished using up the paint bought with the $56.00 sanction you kindly made for the purchase of paint. The playrooms, bathrooms, washrooms, toilets, and hall way in the basement have all received a three coat job, and look exceedingly improved. They are so much lighter and more cheerful, but better still, they are so much more sanitary.

This is a good time of the year to paint, as it is more or less a slack time. I would like very much to have the same job done on the dormitory walls, as well as the dining room. We have had quite a lot of sickness during the last year. We started with Scarlet Fever, Tuberculosis meningitis, Measles, Chicken pox, and just recently the Flu. I feel it would be the best way of putting the building into a sanitary condition by painting the walls of the dormitories, so that they can be washed down after these epidemics, which are liable to come to us at any time.

I estimate that $150.00 would be required to buy paint for this work, and we would do the work of painting ourselves. Will you kindly consider this matter, and if possible, allow us to continue this work of painting.

Your obedient servant,

Chas. F. Hives

Dear Mr. Crerar,-

Some thirty years ago or more, the Department of Indian Affairs constructed a water-main from the easterly limits of the City, to the Shingwauk Home, a distance of approximately one mile. The main is a 3" wrought-iron pipe line and the City delivers water to the Shingwauk Home at the commencement of the line and charges on a meter basis for the water used. For the last year or so, complaints have been made as to the condition of the main and breaks and leaks which have occurred, with the result that both the Public Utilities Commission, who supplies the water service, and the Superintendent of the Home, the Rev. Mr. Hives, are of the opinion that it will be necessary to replace the present main with a new one. The Public Utilities Commission, which I will refer to hereafter as the City, at the present time are servicing no customers east of the Shingwauk Home and only three along the mile 3" line laid by the Department as stated. MEMORANDUM FOR FILE:

When I visited the Shingwauk Home at the first of this month, the Principal directed my attention to the water situation at the school.

The water used at Shingwauk Home is obtained from the City of Sault Ste. Marie. The city water main is approximately one mile from the school and from this point to the school a three inch pipe was installed by the school at the expense of the school authorities some thirty years ago. Since that time two or three other people living between the town limits and the school have been allowed to tap this pipe and use water. There is a meter at the point where the water pipe to the school connects with the city main and there are also meters at the points where the school water pipe has been tapped by residents. Strict account is therefore kept of the water used by each party. In many years past, it has cost the school between $200 and $300 a year for their water.

As a result of grading, etc., along the road where the school's water pipe runs, considerable earth has been removed from above the pipe line and it is not at the same depth as it was when originally installed. There is, therefore, some danger from frost.

About one-half mile behind the Shingwauk Home a new development has recently opened and several homes are being built. These people are requesting the city authorities to supply them with water. The City of Sault Ste. Marie has expressed a desire to replace the present 3" pipe with a 6" pipe and carry this latter pipe to the new development. This would permit them to supply water en-route both to the Shingwauk Home and any other "white" residents who may be living either between the school and the town limits, or behind the school.

The estimated cost of this new pipe line would be $11,000 and the City of Sault Ste. Marie has suggested to Reverend Mr. Hives that the Indian Affairs Branch should pay...
the cost of this pipe line. Mr. Hives does not consider that the City is justified in requesting us to pay for this pipe line, as the present one is suitable for our purposes and the primary object in installing a new pipe line is to provide water for "white" residents along the road.

Mr. Hives states that we could easily dig a well and obtain our own water supply for approximately $3,000.

This report is therefore placed on file for information of the Branch, in the event of a formal application being made for us to pay for the new pipe line.

Memorandum:

Mr. Mills,

Re: Water supply Pipe System,
Shingwauk Home,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.

In accordance with instructions received, an inspection was made on January 24th, of the water supply pipes in the basement of the above school.

This system, installed about two and one-half years ago was installed in the backfill below the six inch concrete basement floor slab. The samples of corroded pipe forwarded to this office by the Indian Affairs branch were removed from beneath the floor slab in the dining room adjacent to the Valve and Catch Pit as shown and marked "A" on the attached plan. The pipes at this point are embedded in about six inches of cinders, used for backfill, and at this point are badly corroded. A sample of this fill, taken from immediately around a piece of corroded pipe has been examined by the Testing Laboratories of the Department of Public Works and as shown in the attached report dated January 31st, 1938, the corrosion is due to electrolytic action set up between the carbon in the cinders and the iron pipe. It is noted that the only remedy is to remove all cinders from the vicinity of the pipes.

In view of the lack of definite information available as to the use and location of cinders, and also as the pipes are located beneath a monolithic concrete slab, test openings were made in the concrete flooring at the points marked "B" and "C" on the attached plan. These points were selected as being at junctions of runs and under plain concrete flooring. The pipe line under floors of the recreation, kitchen, toilet and wash rooms, were not investigated at this time as these floor slabs are surfaced with either terrazzo or special mastic floor finish.

In each of these test holes, with the exception of "A", the pipes were found to be embedded in dry gravel and sand, free from cinders, and in perfectly sound condition. It would appear therefore, that the cinders had not been used throughout the building, and are only placed in contact with the piping in occasional places. Due to some repair work required last year.....

T. S. Mills, Esq.,
Chief Engineer,
Engineering & Construction Service,
Surveys & Engineering Branch
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Indian Affairs. (RC 16, Volume 6213, file 469-5, part 6)
In considering the erection of the building, it is possible that cinders which were used only for extra backfill, were used to a greater extent under the portion of the building occupied by the main recreation room and accompanying services, as the natural grade at this point was considerably lower than under the remaining portion of the building. Consequently it is probable, considering this information and the evidence of the test holes, that the greater portion of the pipe lines are not in contact with cinders and would still be in a satisfactory and serviceable condition.

Before undertaking to repair the system, it would be considered advisable to make tests in order to determine the condition of the piping. A pressure test of the various sections of the system, i.e., "B" to "C", "C to K", "G to D", etc., could be made to determine whether or not there are holes in the pipe due to corrosion. However this test would not determine the condition of the pipe other than for complete corrosion and leakage. A galvanometric test might be made of the sections to determine whether the pipe was being subject to corrosive action provided the action was occurring at the time of the test and not merely suspended due to lack of moisture. These two tests should determine the amount of piping that would have to be repaired immediately, and in all probability would disclose all existing defects. If these tests disclose leaks or corrosive action, the defective sections can be excavated and replaced, or discarded and new sections installed below grade, providing the cost would not be out of proportion or excessive to the estimated cost of $1,100.00 for replacement of the entire system above grade. If no leaks or corrosive action are disclosed the corroded section from "A" to "B" can be removed and replaced with new pipe properly protected from the cinders.

In view of the thorough corrosion of the pipe at "A" it is felt that if the piping does not show leaks or active signs of electrolysis at present, the pipe, in all probability, is not laid in cinders, and therefore would remain in a serviceable condition.

In investigating this trouble it is noted in the specifications that under the concrete sections, paragraph 11, namely, "concrete floors" states that "the basement floors shall be laid on a 6" base of concrete mixed as specified for walls, under this base shall be laid four inches of broken stone or gravel". Also under the Plumbing and Drainage section, paragraph 8, namely "hangers" states that "all piping throughout the building shall be exposed".

Considering these two points of the specifications embodied in the contract agreement for the erection of the building, the installation of the water supply piping below the concrete floor and the use of cinders as backfill are a direct deviation from the specifications. Mr. Thomas R. Wilks, the Supervising Architect employed on the construction was questioned as to these two changes or deviations, but could not state why the cinders were used or why the piping was laid underground. Mr. C. Fitzpatrick, the Contractor, was then called upon and only stated that the work was carried out to the approval of the Supervising Architect and the Architect of the Indian Affairs Branch; As the plumbing had been sublet, Mr. McClary, of

Dunseath & McClary...........
Dunseath & McClary, the Plumbing Contractors, was consulted, and whereas he identified the piping diagram on the enclosed plan as prepared by him and the notes thereon as his comments, he could not say whether the work had been approved by the Architect, but stated that the work had been carried out to the satisfaction of the Contractor and the Supervising Architect. When questioned about the cinder fill Mr. McClary further stated that he had required the cinders to be kept away from the pipes, and in several instances had had cinders removed and replaced with gravel or earth backfill. The contractor's foreman was also questioned as to the use of cinders but as in all other cases, could not state definitely how or where the cinders were used in relationship to the piping.

(Note - As a result of the above consultations the five test holes were excavated in an attempt to ascertain where cinders had been used and also as to the probable condition of the piping. The Plumber's statement regarding the cinder fill further substantiates the previous statement that the greater portion of the pipe lines are not in contact with cinders)

In considering the responsibility for the corrosion of the pipes, which is a direct result of their location and the use of the cinders it should be noted that the general conditions, paragraph C, namely "Additions and Deductions" states that "No deviation from the plans and specifications will be permitted without the direct consent of the Department in writing..." and further "Should the architect at any time during the progress of the work desire any alterations, additions or omissions from the work as provided for in the plans and specifications, the architect shall have the right to issue orders and directions in the matter and the same shall in no way affect or make void the contract. No such alterations, additions or omissions shall be instituted, however, without authority in writing."

In addition, paragraph 15, namely "Guarantees" states that "The occupation of the whole or any part of the building will not be considered as an acceptance of the work, and furthermore the final inspection and acceptance of the work shall not be conclusive or binding upon the Department, if it should subsequently be found that inferior workmanship or materials have been incorporated into the building or that the contract had been departed from in any way. Any and all costs for making good such discrepancies shall be chargeable to the Contractor together with any and all damages that may have resulted because of defective workmanship and materials or either".

The installation of the water supply piping below the floor level, and the use of cinders as backfill for the basement floor slabs, constitute a direct deviation from the specifications, and whereas these changes were instituted without authority in writing, can be considered as defective workmanship, and therefore, under paragraph 1b, of the General Conditions, any and all costs for making good such discrepancies might be chargeable to the Contractor, together with any and all damages that may have resulted because of defective workmanship.

Respectfully submitted,

Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle,

Re: Shingwauk Home
Sault Ste. Marie.

With reference to your memorandum of January 19th, an inspection of the water pipe system located in the basement of the above school was made by Mr. Dudley on January 24th. You will note from the attached report of February 5th that the present trouble is due to electrolytic corrosive action set up between the cinders of the cinder backfill and the iron pipe, and that the only remedy is to remove all cinders from the vicinity of the pipes.

However, from the information obtained by the investigation, it is not considered necessary to replace the entire system as it appears from the test holes excavated at various points of the building, that the cinders were not used throughout and that where the pipe is laid in sand or gravel it is in satisfactory condition.

In order to put the system in working order a pressure test should be applied to the various sections of the system and any leaking sections replaced. The extent of the replacements would depend upon the location of the leakages, such as under an extensive floor area, such as section "B" - "H" or "B"-"G" as shown on the floor plan; it would be more economical to replace the entire section with new supply lines above floor level. However, if leaks are discovered in sections such as "A"-"H" or "B"-"C" it would be advisable to excavate these sections and replace the defective pipe with new lengths properly protected. This latter procedure should be followed for the corroded section "A"-"B" in the event that no other leakages are disclosed.

The cost of this work can only be determined by the results of the pressure test, but should be in proportion to the estimated cost of $1,100.00 for the replacement of the entire system at the floor level. On this basis it is estimated that the section "A"-"H" could be replaced for about $50.00 or $60.00, and the maximum cost of the repairs required..........

Marie to represent the Department of Indian Affairs, the contractor and the plumbing sub-contractor, it appears that these changes, which were directly responsible for the present trouble, were carried out without authority in writing. Dear Sir:

I am sorry to have to report an outbreak of fire, which occurred on Thursday morning last, and while I was away escorting three children to the Sanatorium at Nixi, Hull, P.Q. As far as I can make out, a boy of fourteen years of age, threw some gasoline on the furnace to kindle it, and which resulted in an explosion. Had it not been for the prompt action of members of the staff, and the City Fire Brigade, the Principal's residence would have been destroyed very quickly. As it was, considerable damage was done to the floor and walls of the building. The firemen had to break into the walls in order to extinguish the fire. The electric wiring in the basement is also out of commission, and the walls of the house are very badly blackened up, and will require painting.

I have made an estimate of the cost of restoration, and have also asked the advice of two reliable contractors, and estimate it will cost two hundred and fifty dollars to buy the material and do most of the work ourselves. The plastering and electrical work will have to be done by experts.

I am very sorry indeed that this has happened, and beg to assure you it was not on account of any negligence on the part of Mrs Hives or the staff. I have repeatedly warned pupils never on any account to interfere with gasoline, and there was absolutely no need for the boy to have put anything on the fire to urge it to burn. The trouble is, we are dealing with children who are, sometimes, very difficult to deal with, and to instruct.

Will you kindly let me know at the very earliest your wishes regarding the work of restoring. Until I receive them, the wiring is useless, and things around the house are very much disorganized.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Principal.

Reverend Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 4th instant with reference to the fire in the Principal's residence at the Shingwauk Home. It is difficult to understand why gasoline was apparently left in such a convenient place that the person starting the fire was able to obtain it. I note that most of the work will be done by the school staff but in connection with the purchase of material I would point out that present regulations do not permit our authorizing principals to make these purchases. It is necessary for all purchases to be made through our Purchasing Branch.

You should, therefore, let me have detailed information regarding the materials that you require to repair the damage that was caused.

You may arrange for the plastering and electrical work but before engaging any labour you should consult Indian Agent Sims with a view to obtaining the names on his approved list. It is expected, of course, that you will give these repairs your personal supervision and keep the cost as low as possible.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Sir:

Regarding the matter of proposed new barn for Shingwauk School, I would like to submit a few suggestions.

As you are, no doubt, aware, it was the intention of the Department to follow up the erection of the new main building with complete outbuilding, and the plans, a copy of which was sent to me last spring, were drawn up by the late Mr. Gurney Orr, as a building in keeping with the main school building and the proper size to accommodate the necessary number of cattle and horses we require. The plans are a little more elaborate than is necessary and could be modified considerably in order to cut down the cost, but, in the main, they are what we need, and I would very strongly recommend their adoption.

I understand the estimate for the construction of the barn would be around $10,000.00, if given a contractor, but I have also made a very careful estimate, after getting prices, etc., and find it could be built at a cost not exceeding $6,000.00, if done by day labour and under the supervision of a competent master builder. A $2,500.00 barn would not accommodate our stock, (I understand from you that is the amount of money at present available) and would build only a horse stable or a small cow barn, either of which would not be convenient for size or supervision and both of which we urgently require; and for the sake of proper supervision of the boys, if at all possible, under one roof.

I would therefore recommend that the plans now in hand be adopted in the main and that the building be started immediately, while we are enjoying good building weather; that it should be done by day labour and that Mr. Luke Langdon, of Sault Ste. Marie, be master builder. The local member, Mr. H. Hamilton, is quite in favour of this man. I recommend that the gravel and cement be purchased from I. J. Downey & Son, of Sault Ste. Marie,

Oct. 29, 1938.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I am writing you in connection with the water main between Shingwauk and the city of Sault Ste. Marie. Yesterday the city Water Commissioner and I met in the office of the Indian Agent, and after talking matters over, we decided to have holes dug in various parts of the pipe line in order to have the pipe properly inspected by someone competent. Five holes were dug, and we brought a good plumber down to test the pipes, and he reported them in very bad condition from corrosion. These pipes have been laid for about forty years, and under their present state would not bear any tampering with.

When the pipes were laid, the road, which at that time was a one wagon trail, has been widened, so that now, the pipe line is well on to the road, and I was quite shocked to find it had only thirty inches of earth over it. During this week, the city have been taking down a hill in the road, and the pipe at that point is from nine to twelve inches under the surface, and for a distance of about two hundred and fifty feet. Until looking into matters, I did not realize how serious is the situation.

I am convinced something must be done, and done immediately, or our water and heating system is almost bound to collapse during the Winter, and we would be quite helpless to do anything.

The City Water Commission are very anxious to cooperate with us in the matter, though how far they can be made to go is the question. It is a ten thousand dollar job, no matter who does it, or when it is done, and it will have to be done by someone, and unless we are to suffer during the winter -
the winter, it must be done immediately, for the situation is quite serious.

Had I known things were so serious when I was in Ottawa, I would have discussed the matter with you more thoroughly. As it is, I feel we should get together on it, for I am convinced it is of such importance as to warrant our doing so, and I am sure the Commission of our Church Society would want me to do so.

Will you kindly let me know as soon as possible your wishes in the matter, and in the meantime, I will obtain as much information as possible from the City Commissioner as to how far they would go in the matter of financing it. I have the feeling they will go a long way if they are properly approached. On Monday next, I shall seek all the information I can, after which I would like to get into touch with you, and would be prepared to meet with you in your office at any time should you think it worth while my doing so.

Yours faithfully,

(Sgd.) Chas. F. Hives,

Ottawa, November 1, 1938.

Dear Mr. Hives:

I was greatly disturbed to learn from your letter of the 29th ultimo that the water main connecting Shingwauk Indian Residential School with the water supply of Sault Ste. Marie was urgently in need of repair.

No provision has been made, either in this year's or next year's estimates, for repairs or alterations at your school, other than a grant of $2,500.00 for the completion of the barn.

It is my intention to ask the Surveys and Engineering Branch to send up a man with the object of having a thorough investigation made of the water supply at your school. In the meantime, you might secure if you can figures indicating the extent to which the city of Sault Ste. Marie are prepared to cooperate with us, should we decide to proceed with the project. The cost of securing water by the construction of a well on the school grounds should also be carefully investigated. It is exceedingly difficult, if not impossible, to justify an expenditure of $10,000. for the water supply at your school, in view of the hundreds of demands that are reaching us daily from other sections of the Dominion. I do not consider that it will be at all necessary for you to visit Ottawa until you hear from us again.

Yours very truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Memorandum:

Mr. Mills,

Re: Water Supply, Shingwauk Indian Residential School, Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario.

According to instructions I made a trip to Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario, to investigate the present water supply of the Shingwauk Indian School at that place.

I found that the above school is supplied by a 5 inch pipe which connects with the city main near the corner of Queen and Pine streets. As this pipe has been in place for 40 years it has suffered considerable corrosion and will have to be replaced sooner or later. During grading operations on the road only a foot of covering was left over the pipe at one place, and in addition due to widening of the roadway, a considerable length of pipe is now in the roadbed, with only 30 inches of covering over it. This depth has been sufficient up to the present since the pipe was to one side and clear of the roadway, as this allowed the snow to remain over it all winter, and in addition it received further protection from the ridge which the snow plough left. When the attention of the city officials was drawn to this matter they had the earth covering replaced over the pipe to its former depth where necessary, and they also agreed to have the road ploughed in such a manner as to leave a ridge of snow over the pipe at other places.

At present the only fire protection at the Shingwauk School is in the main school building where there is a fire riser with 1½ inch hose outlets at each floor. There is no outside hydrant to protect the other buildings, and as the main building is of modern fireproof construction, it would seem that the greater need is for the outside hydrant. However, it will be seen that even with an outside fire hydrant the 3 inch supply pipe would be inadequate, especially as it is 40 years old and over a mile long.

T. S. MILLS, Esq.,
Chief Engineer,
Engineering & Construction Service,
Surveys & Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Indian Affairs. (RG 1C, Volume 6213, file 469-5, part 6)
The Public Utilities Commission of Sault Ste. Marie does not receive any share of the general taxes but has to finance its different projects through bank loans; these loans, with interest, being a charge against the actual work and paid by the users benefitting. Where the improvement is carried past vacant properties these do not have to share in the cost unless they have service connections and are actually using the water. In the case of the Shingwauk School, in the first half mile, there are two or three private residences and a public park using the water and the owners will contribute half the cost if the Utilities Commission lays a 6 inch main, and the school will contribute the other half. The payment for the work would be spread over a period of twenty years with interest at 5% unless some other arrangements were made with the Utilities Commission.

The fire underwriters insist on a 6 inch main as minimum where the municipality is responsible for the work, although a smaller main might be laid here if the school assumed the cost of the whole work. A smaller main of 4 inch bore would not be adequate for outside fire protection, although it would provide considerably more water than is now obtained through the old 3 inch main and at a much better pressure. The cost of a 4 inch main would be about $3,000.00 more than half the cost of a 6 inch main and consequently the school would be much better off if a 6 inch main were laid. In addition the 6 inch main would be maintained by the Commission.

The cost of laying a 6 inch main would be in the neighborhood of $10,000.00, the school being responsible for half of this amount. As stated before the payments would be spread over a period of twenty years and would include yearly interest on the money. In addition to the above the school buildings are mostly located about 400 feet from the highway and it would be necessary to lay this amount of pipe in the school grounds if fire hydrants were desired close to the buildings. This would add from $600.00 to $800.00 to the total cost, depending upon the location of the hydrant. It is understood that the Commission would supply a hydrant but this is not absolutely certain. The cost of a 4 inch main would be about $8,000.00 plus about $600.00 for the pipe between the highway and the school buildings and, as stated before, the school would have to bear the entire cost of this plus any maintenance that was required.

The possibility of a deep well supply was also investigated but it would appear that this would cost practically as much as the city water supply with the added maintenance costs and supervision. There are several successful wells in the district but it was stated that although good results were obtained in some cases, in others in close proximity the results were negative. It was not possible to obtain figures for drilling wells but at the Provincial House of Refuge a well is in use for which the installation cost...
installation cost $2,500.00 and the Pump House $500.00. The pressure tank of 1600 gallons capacity was already in place when the pump was installed and the well had been in use for some time. It is estimated that the tank would cost $1,000.00 and the cost of drilling the well would be $1,500.00 altogether, so that the total cost would be around $5,000.00. Dr. Shepherd, the Medical Supervisor of the institution, was of the opinion that if city water could be secured it would be infinitely preferable to a well and pump installation. The above installation uses a 10 H.P. single phase motor, the pump having a capacity of 100 American gallons per minute.

It would appear that the most economical and satisfactory arrangement for the Shingwauk School would be for it to secure its water supply from the city through a 4 inch main as proposed, as it would probably be possible for the Department to pay its share as the work progressed and thus save interest charges on the cost. Apparently the existing 3 inch pipe has passed through several winters without damage from frost and it may do so again, and although the present lack of snow is not a very favourable condition in this regard, the mild winter climate seems to be conducive to it. However, the condition of the pipe is such that any sudden increase in pressure or water hammer might cause damage to it, and consequently it would seem advisable to replace it as soon as funds are available.

Respectfully submitted,
December 13, 1936.

Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle,

Re: Water Supply Shingwauk Indian Residential School, Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.

In reference to your memorandum of the 5th ultimo enclosing copy of a memorandum from the Director of Indian Affairs in regard to the above matter, I attach hereto a copy of Mr. Byrne's report, in duplicate, covering his investigation of the matter.

It would appear that owing to the present condition and size of the existing 3-inch supply main to the Shingwauk school, the main should be replaced when funds are available. Three alternative proposals are considered:

1. Laying a new 6-inch main between the City main and the school, the cost of same to be equally divided between the Water Commission and the school.

2. Laying a new 4-inch main between the City main and school, the whole cost to be borne by the Department as well as the cost of maintenance and upkeep.

3. By a deep well installation on the school grounds, the entire cost of which, plus maintenance and supervision, would have to be borne by the Department.

The estimated cost of a 6-inch pipe line would be $10,000.00, of which the Department would pay $5,000.00 plus interest at 5 per cent, unless some arrangement were made to pay as the work progressed. In addition to the above, the whole cost of the lateral from the highway into the school grounds would have to be met by the Department.

The estimated cost of a 4-inch pipe line would be $8,000.00 plus the cost of the lateral between the highway and school, all of which would have to be paid by the Department as well as the upkeep and maintenance of same. The estimated first cost of a complete deep well installation would be $5,300.00 and in addition there would be the yearly maintenance, upkeep, and operating costs to consider.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER,

In a memorandum dated November 1, 1938, the Director of the Surveys and Engineering Branch was requested to undertake an investigation of the water supply at the Shingwauk Indian Residential School.

I am now in receipt of a report from the Surveys and Engineering Branch which reads in part as follows:

"Several alterations were considered for the supply of water to this school, including Mr. Hives' suggestion of a well. Briefly Mr. Byrne's recommendation is that a fifty-fifty cost arrangement be entered into with the Public Utilities Commission of Sault Ste. Marie for the installation of a 6" main to the school at an estimated cost of $10,000, half of which amount would be paid by the Department. In addition to this there would, of course, be the lateral running from the highway to the school at a cost of approximately $600 or $800."

The Shingwauk Residential School has at this date a pupil enrolment of 130. The school is being supplied with water from a 3 inch pipe which connects with the Sault Ste. Marie city main near the corner of Queen and Pine streets. This 3 inch main has been in place for over 40 years. It has suffered considerably from corrosion and should be replaced just as soon as funds for its replacement can be secured.

No provision was made in the estimates of this fiscal year for the installation of a new water supply at the -
at the Shingwauk School nor has any provision been made for such a project in the estimates for the fiscal year 1939-40. You are probably aware that provision was made in the estimates of this year for the construction of a new barn at this school, the cost of which will be met by the payment of $2,500 out of this year's estimates and $2,500 out of the 1939-40 estimates.

The suggestion has been made that the new water main might be laid by day labour and thus give employment to a large number of unskilled workers and that the cost be borne by the city of Sault Ste. Marie, the Provincial Government and the Dominion Government; in other words, that this work be recognized as a worthwhile unemployment relief project. If it cannot be recognized as a relief project, provision should be made in the supplementary estimates for an amount necessary to undertake and complete this work.

I shall await your instructions before making a definite recommendation.

Director.

MEMORANDUM OF AGREEMENT entered into this day of June, A.D. 1939:

BETWEEN:

HIS MAJESTY THE KING, in the right of the Dominion of Canada, represented herein by the Honourable Thomas A. Crerar, Minister of Mines and Resources for the Dominion of Canada, hereinafter referred to as "His Majesty"

OF THE FIRST PART,

and

THE PUBLIC UTILITIES COMMISSION OF SAULT STE. MARIE, hereinafter called the "Commission"

OF THE SECOND PART.

WHEREAS His Majesty assists in the operation of an Indian School, known as the Shingwauk Indian Residential School, in the City of Sault Ste. Marie, in the Province of Ontario, and has agreed with the Commission to contribute to the cost of the construction of a six inch cast iron water main on the terms and conditions hereinafter set forth.

NOW THEREFORE THIS AGREEMENT WITNESSETH that in consideration of the premises and the payment by His Majesty of one-half of the cost of the water main hereinafter described, or the sum of Five Thousand ($5,000.00) Dollars, whichever amount shall be the lesser, the Parties hereto agree each with
the other as follows:

1.- The Commission shall proceed with and complete during the year 1939, the construction of a six inch cast iron water main on Queen Street, East, in the said City of Sault Ste. Marie, from the easterly limit of the present eight inch water main of the Commission on Queen Street near Pine Street, to a point opposite the westerly limit of the roadway running north from said Queen Street to the east of the Shingwauk Chapel, into the said Shingwauk Indian Residential School.

2.- His Majesty shall pay to the Commission on or before the first day of September, 1940, one-half of the cost of the said water main or the sum of Five Thousand ($5,000.00) Dollars, whichever shall be the lesser amount, without interest, and if the said sum is not paid by September first, 1940, interest at the rate of five (5%) percent per annum shall be paid by His Majesty to the Commission until the said amount is fully paid and satisfied.

3.- The said water main shall consist of a six inch cast iron pipe, properly laid and joined in accordance with recognized standards of practice in connection with such works in the City of Sault Ste. Marie.

4.- The said work shall be performed subject to inspection and approval by His Majesty's representatives.
or officials, and every opportunity and facility shall be accorded to such representative or official for that purpose.

5.- Upon completion of the said work, the said water main shall be and remain the property of the said Commission and they may connect other services thereto as they may deem advisable, provided however, that a continuous supply of water and the average water pressure obtaining in the City of Sault Ste. Marie as a whole, shall be maintained in respect to the water service of the said Shingwauk Indian Residential School.

6.- The Commission shall supply water service through the water main constructed hereunder and the Commission will charge the said Shingwauk Indian Residential School the usual and regular water service rates applying from time to time throughout the City of Sault Ste. Marie.

7.- "Cost" as referred to herein, shall mean and include the cost of material supplied and labour performed in connection with the construction of the said water main as provided herein but shall not include any overhead charges or supervision charges on the part of the Commission or its officials.

8.- The Commission shall install and maintain for service, at the terminal of the said six inch water main to be
constructed as herein provided for, a standard fire hydrant, and at the point where the present water supply enters the grounds of the said Shingwauk Indian Residential School from Queen Street, or such other point as may be designated by His Majesty's representatives prior to reaching such point in the laying of the said six inch main, shall install a 6 - 6 - 4 T with valve for connecting up the said six inch main to the smaller pipe line leading to said School.

9.- This Agreement shall ensue to the benefit of and be binding upon the parties hereto, their successors and assigns.

IN WITNESS WHEREOF the parties hereto have hereunto set their hands and seals.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

The Rev. Principal Hives of our Shingwauk School has reported to our Commission the need of some playground equipment for the school children. He points out that as most of the children are unable to go home for their holidays the need becomes all the greater during that period of the year. He can secure a set of three swings and one "merry-go-round swing" which has long ropes with a ring on the end and have the same installed at the total cost of $114.00. The boys of the school have already made a splendid effort to raise this amount but so far they have only managed to be able to secure $60.00, and our Commission would like to know if your Department of Government could provide the remaining $54.00. It will surely be an encouragement to these boys if you can secure for them this amount, or as generous a contribution as your funds will admit.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

TBRW/WH
Secretary of the Commission.
Ottawa,
August 3, 1939.

Reverend Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 26th ultimo with reference to playground equipment at the Shingwauk residential school.

During the latter part of the last fiscal year and the first part of this fiscal year an amount of approximately $5000.00 has been expended at the Shingwauk Home for the erection of a new barn.

In our appropriation for next year we will have to provide another $5000.00 for installing a new water main from the city of Sault Ste. Marie to the school.

You will note from the above that we are endeavouring to deal fairly with the Shingwauk Home and I regret that as no funds were specifically provided for the type of playground equipment mentioned in your letter the expenditure requested cannot be authorized.

Yours truly,

Sept. II, 1939.

Dear Mr Phelan:

I have been making enquiries about lumber required for finishing off root house, and am enclosing a letter from Ed. Buchanan of Echo Bay. I made other enquiries from lumber companies, and the Baldwin Lumber Co., who are on the approved list quote a price of $48.00 per thousand feet for the same class of lumber. You may readily see, therefore, that it will be greatly to our advantage to buy from Buchanan. Furthermore, Ed. Buchanan buys his logs for sawing from the Indians of Garden River, and practically all his saw mill labour is Indian labour. In fact, it was on this consideration that permission was given me to buy lumber from him for the building of our new barn. I would therefore recommend that the lumber we require now, should be purchased from Mr Buchanan.

Will you kindly let me have your reply as soon as possible so that the work may be finished in time for storing our potatoes etc.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Dear Sir,

The enclosed letter has just been received, and there is not much I can add to what is there, beyond endorsing the facts stated. It was in the plans to build a properly constructed septic tank for the disposal of the sewage when the school was completed, but owing to the death of the architect and financial limitations, this matter has been side-tracked. Many verbal complaints have come in prior to the enclosed, and we have tried to smooth the matter over by applying some deodorant etc., and saying we do no worse than the city. But, the matter will have to be remedied sometime, not only on account of their complaints, but for our own sakes, because it is really more of a nuisance to us than it is to them. And there is more than the possibility of disease arising from such a condition.

In my opinion there is only one remedy, and that is to build a septic tank capable of handling the sewage. This, I estimate, would cost in the neighbourhood of $800.00 if we do most of the work ourselves.

In the meantime, will you kindly think the matter over, and if it cannot possibly be attended to during the next fiscal year, I will tell these gentlemen it will be attended to as soon as the war is over, if you think this would be best.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Sir:

During my recent visit to your office, I was informed of a certain sum of money allocated for general improvements for Shingwauk Home, and was asked to send in a list of paint etc. required. I enclose herewith list of paint, amounting to approximately $200.00. I am also enclosing two quotations of prices for same. I would recommend that the Cochrane Dunlop receive the order, for they are not only low in their prices, but they are always reliable, and my experience is they give good value for money.

The spire and tower on the main building will require painting and some repairs. I would not want to have the boys doing this work, though they can do much of the other safe painting. I would therefore have to hire an experienced man to help me put up the scaffold and do the painting. This work, along with necessary expenses which may come up in connection with the tower and spire painting would cost $100.00.

We have no garage in connection with the school. I would like, if possible, to use the remaining $200.00 for the building of a garage for the school car and truck. I would use up the lumber required for the scaffolding of the tower on this job, and would recommend that I be allowed to purchase what other lumber we require from Ed. Buchanan, Echo Bay. This man has a saw mill, and employs Indian labour at his mill. I can get good lumber from him at a greatly reduced price, and for this reason, would recommend that all lumber be purchased from him.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Principal

Dear Sir,-

I have just heard that two old buildings of considerable architectural interest on the Shingwauk Indian Reserve are about to be altered by the Superintendent. They are built in a manner rare in this country, i.e., in half timber. My informant advises me that the work may have started already. I should be greatly obliged if you would investigate this matter. If it is being done under your instructions I have confidence that it will be well done, but if there is any way of saving the buildings in their present form, I feel it would be worth doing.

Dear Sirs:

The Ontario Association of Architects has heard with regret of the possible demolition of the original Shingwauk Indian School, near Sault Ste. Marie. We feel that the preservation of this building is a matter of architectural and historical interest, and would appreciate your consideration and action to that end.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 16th inst., relative to the matter of demolition of old buildings connection with the old Shingwauk Home. In the first place, I would like to say, the building in question is already demolished. When the old school was demolished, I was given orders, by your Department, through the late Mr Orr, Architect, to get rid of the old hospital building as soon as possible. I promised to do this, but have not had the chance to carry out that promise until the last two months. The reason for this was that our school Engineer and his wife and family lived in part of the building, which consisted of a frame structure of three rooms and a pantry, and he had to live there until another house was available. This other house became available during this Summer, and with certain improvements, for which I have asked your sanction, can be made comfortable for the Engineer.

The late Mr Orr, gave his orders for the demolition of the building from a landscape point of view. But there are two very specific reasons why it was advisable to have it demolished. First, because it was unsafe. The building was a stone veneer, built on a wood foundation. The foundation was decayed, and the walls were falling down. Ours is a school for boys and girls, and in spite of all supervision, boys will prospect an old house, and this house was unsafe.

Secondly, the house in question was the old hospital. Goodness knows what disease, of an infectious nature had been isolated in it. From the standpoint of sanitation it was advisable to have it demolished. I was not able to put the boys to work on the house, partly because it was not safe for them to do such a work, and partly because it was not sanitary. I therefore made arrangements with a man to demolish it for the bit of lumber he could salvage.

I assure you, sir, the demolition of the old
Hospital is a good job done, and the land in front of the main building will be improved thereby.

It seems funny that there are these sentimental people around, who would interfere with progress such as has been going on during the last six or seven years at Shingwauk. They tried in every way to stop the demolition of the old main building, which would have been a menace in every way, had it remained. And yet those same people, who claim to take such an interest in historical sites etc., would pass by an old cemetery where the old timers of the Soo are buried, and never give a hand to care for it.

I would be very glad indeed to give you further explanation if such is necessary.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Principal.

Dear Sir,

Enclosed letter was received yesterday following a visit last week of a committee of local doctors. As you can understand the C.D.C. is very anxious to be prepared for all emergencies. I explained to the doctors that I had no power to allow the use of this building for any purpose whatever, but that I should be pleased to pass on their request to you if they would send me a letter which could be forwarded to the Indian Department.

In an emergency we could manage to hand over one of the dormitories on the second floor for use as a hospital ward, and also a room in the infirmary which might be used for emergency operations. This could be kept quite apart from the rest of the school while in use for this purpose and need not seriously interfere with the regular routine.

Dear Mr. Minchin:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 2nd instant and also a communication received by you from the Civilian Defence Committee of Sault Ste. Marie, sent forward therewith.

This is the first request of its kind that has reached us since the outbreak of the war. It is noted with interest that in an emergency you could place at the disposal of the committee one of the dormitories on the second floor, for use as a hospital, and a room in the infirmary which might be used for emergency operations, and that this concession would not seriously interfere with the regular routine of the school.

It is our earnest hope that no emergency will arise, that would render necessary the use of this accommodation by the Civilian Defence Committee. Should the need develop, however, I feel sure that it would be the desire of the Government to do everything humanly possible to assist the committee in alleviating human suffering. You are authorized, therefore, to cooperate with the committee in working out the best ways and means of safeguarding the interests of the population of Sault Ste. Marie and the immediate district.

Dear Sir:

Re: Shingwauk School Floors

In reply to your letter of October 5th last, 13-0-5, I may say that I have obtained the gratuitous opinion of Mr. K.G. Ross, a qualified engineer of the firm of Lang & Ross, in this matter.

The finishing surface of neat cement has worn or flaked off in large areas and there is continued erosion of the mass cement beneath. A paint surface would prevent this erosion.

It is suggested to give the whole of the floor surfaces two coats concrete floor enamel and thereafter touch up the worn spots with enamel when they occur. This would prevent further wear and deterioration.
