March 16th, 1944.

Dear Sir:

I enclose herewith our account in duplicate for material and labour supplied for repairing flashings and roof where shingles were blown off.

In the steeple, we made a careful examination of the same from the inside and find that the galvanized iron louvers are in bad shape; a good number of them are loose where the soldering has broken at the ends and they are drooping down. Where the vertical part joins to the tapered portion, daylight can be seen in numerous places and there is no doubt that this is where the steeple leaks. In order to reach this, a scaffold would have to be built straddling the roof, in order to get up to do the work, as nothing can be done with this from the inside. It is difficult to estimate the amount of time required to repair the steeple, until a scaffold has been built, but it would cost at least $100.00 to build and remove scaffolding and repair the metal work.

As plastering in the laundry, it is our opinion that the cause of the plaster peeling off above the end of the washing machine, is that the steam is the cause of the trouble and the only remedy is to have the ceiling plastered with cement plaster and then painted. The ceiling at the present time is plastered with gypsum and this will not stand moisture.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Dear Sir:

During the recent dull weather we have been obliged
to depend upon the electric lighting in the classrooms and we
shall have to make use of this very considerably during the winter
months. We also have to use one classroom every evening for the
children to do their homework:- Those attending Collegiate and
Technical School as well as our own grades VII and VIII. I have
had the lighting tested and find it altogether inadequate. The
electrician I have consulted, who has been installing lighting
into a number of schools, recommends the following:-

Approved Schoolroom fixtures should be installed in all
classrooms with 200 watt capacity, also blackboard
reflectors.

This would require:-

22 Schoolroom fixtures @ $8.00- $176.00
9 Blackboard reflectors @ $5.00- $45.00

Would you be kind enough to bring this matter to the attention
of the Department as I consider the change to be very necessary
especially as quite a number of the children appear to be suffering
from eyestrain.

Yours very truly,

Arthur E. Minchin,
principal
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Dear Sirs,

On September 30th, our District Inspector, Mr. F. Mills, made the annual inspection of H. V. Boiler No. 2 and H. W. Tank Nos. O.A.11692 and O.A.11693, and reports as follows:

Mr. Mills recommends the installation of a larger reducing valve on the cold water inlet to the building, also the maintenance of a continuous cushion of air even above the outlet pipe of the cushion tank at the entrance to the building. At the present time a 2" water line enters the building and the cushion tank, but only 2" x 1" lines at reduced pressure leave the cushion tank to supply the whole school. The result is the pulsating pressure throughout the buildings varying from 0 to 80 or 90 lbs. This sudden change in pressure going on all the time is very hard on the hot water boiler and tanks. It has been necessary to have the Pendell boiler welded at the seams and stays on several occasions due to the above.

The fees chargeable for the above inspections amount to $3.00, which is included in our invoice for $7.50 enclosed herewith. The other equipment listed on the invoice is in satisfactory condition. Certificates will be issued upon receipt of your cheque.

Yours truly,

J. N. BRIGGS,

April 10, 1947.

Re: Shingwauk Home,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario.

An inspection of the mechanical services at the above was carried out by an officer from this Service on February 24th to 26th inclusive, and the results are summarized as follows:

The boiler plant and piping distribution system is of relatively good design and with several exceptions was installed according to the original plans. Most of the equipment appeared to be in good condition, but several items are in need of repair and some additional equipment is necessary if the plant is to function with normal efficiency.

Complaints received indicated a lack of heat in the Class Rooms, Auditorium and Sewing Room. Complaints were also received concerning the lack of domestic hot water.

Much of the heating difficulty can be overcome by releasing the thermostat which controls the entire building, along with several additional radiators located where required.

The original design of the domestic hot water heating equipment was not followed out in its entirety, and while the storage tank is large enough, the heater capacity is definitely inadequate. An undersized coal fired domestic hot water heater is now in use and this unit is too small as well as being in poor condition. The present low pressure heating boilers have ample capacity to heat the building as well as to heat the domestic hot water, if one other was installed.

The domestic hot and cold water piping is all undersized, and most of it is buried under the basement slab in cinder fill which has been the cause of failures due to rapid corrosion. (Incidentally, the main building return from the heating system is also buried under the slab.) All domestic hot and cold risers are undersized and none of this piping is insulated.

While no immediate emergency exists, this buried piping should be replaced and the building return housed in a trench, to prevent further interruptions to these services. A careful analysis of the requirements indicate that the following improvements are necessary to bring this plant up to a reasonably efficient service.

J.M. Hardie, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6213, file 469-5, part 8)
1. Install one stoker to serve one of the present low pressure heating boilers.

2. Provide an indirect steam fed heater of sufficient capacity to adequately handle the domestic hot water requirements.

3. Replace all domestic hot and cold water mains and most of the risers, and properly insulate same.

4. Replace that portion of main building return now buried under basement slab and house new line in concrete trench.

5. Move building thermostat to more favorable location.

6. Add several new radiators in rooms which are now under heated.

7. Provide new jacket heater for summer service only and arrange piping to this end.

8. Arrange with manufacturer to service existing vacuum pump and controls.

It is estimated that the above operations will cost in the neighborhood of $5000.00

This Service now has data from which plans and specifications could be prepared, but we are in no position at present to advise when such work could be undertaken.

The matter of ice formation on the roof was discussed with the Principal. It was pointed out that no satisfactory method of preventing such conditions could be suggested, and the school authorities should arrange with the Indian Agent to have men remove accumulations of snow before ice had a chance to form. The Principal accepted the idea that it was part of the normal maintenance which should be carried out under his direction.

Chief Engineer.

Re: Shingwauk Home-Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.

In connection with Mr. Hoey's memorandum of April 17th, 1947, and your notations of the 19th instant thereon, you are advised as follows:

While it can be fairly stated that no immediate emergency exists at the above, it is also true that the domestic hot and cold water piping now buried under the basement slab, is in a state of progressive deterioration, and the need for continual repairs can be expected. The same situation on other residential schools has resulted in disorganization of the school routine. Should an emergency arise, the repairs would involve cutting the concrete slab and patching worn piping, which in the past has been carried out by the School staff, resulting in considerable neglect to boiler room duties.

If requested by Indian Affairs to prepare plans and specifications for the necessary revisions as outlined in our memorandum of April 10th, 1947, we consider they could be issued for tendering about May 30th next, which would enable the work to be carried out before the beginning of the fall term.

It is felt that this work should be carried out during the current fiscal year if funds can be made available.

May 1st, 1947

In connection with Mr. Hoey's memorandum of April 26th, 1947, and your notation of the 25th instant thereon, regarding the above, you are advised as follows:

When the mechanical services were inspected (February 24th-26th) the condition of the vacuum pump was noted. It was felt at that time following a close check, that the pump would function reasonably well enough for the balance of the heating season. Included in our memorandum of April 10th, 1947, is a clause recommending that the pump be serviced by the manufacturer at the same time as the proposed revisions to the mechanical services are carried out.

This pump has not had shop service since it was installed, and as already stated, no immediate concern was felt when our inspection was made. This is a condition that applies to most of the residential schools and there is no doubt that some elements such as plumbing, etc., are in need of attention. Since the Principal's letter indicates some concern, we feel that Indian Affairs should authorize the manufacturer to examine the pump and make what replacements are necessary as soon as possible. This would avoid the risk of a breakdown.

The pump was manufactured by the C.A. Dunham Co. Ltd. It was supplied by their local agent who is located at 45 Rideau Street, Ottawa. Under the circumstances this firm might be contacted with the view of carrying out the work.

The Principal of our Shingwauk School reports as follows on the major services which are needed at that School:

IMPROVEMENTS TO HEATING SYSTEM

A Mr. Hargraves, an Engineer sent by the Department, examined the heating system in March, 1947, and recommended the installation of a stoker and other improvements. So far the only work carried out has been the overhaul and repair of the vacuum pump by the Dunham people.

HOUSE FOR FARM INSTRUCTOR

There is constant need for a house for the Farm Instructor. No accommodation outside of the main building is provided for any of the staff and the house at present occupied by the Farm Instructor is an old building, owned by the Diocese, which is very difficult to heat. This building has been carefully examined by a committee appointed by the Diocesan Executive, who have reported that it would practically need rebuilding in order to make it habitable in the cold season; this would involve a very heavy expenditure which the Diocese is not prepared to incur as the building is not used for Diocesan purposes.

PROVISION OF A MANUAL TRAINING SHOP

If Manual Training is to be carried on fully, there should be an extension to provide a Manual Training Shop.
It will be appreciated if you will give consideration to the inclusion of the three items mentioned above in your Departmental Estimates, 1948-49.

MEMORANDUM

To: Shingwauk Home,
Sault Ste Marie, Ont.

Further to our memorandum of May 1st, 1947, with reference to the above, you are advised as follows:

We were notified by telephone by the Ottawa Representative of the O.J. Dunham Company, that one of their engineers from Toronto was to be sent to the school at the request of Indian Affairs, to carry out the necessary revisions to the vacuum pump and to examine the automatic controls on the heating system.

The Dunham representative verbally informed us on October 14th, that the pump had been repaired and put back ready for service. Also that the automatic controls on the heating system have been examined and adjusted for normal operation, as it was felt by their engineer that the boiler room staff at the school would get better results by operating the system in this manner for the time being at least.

Following an inspection of the mechanical services by our Mr. Hargreaves last February, it was recommended that at least one stove be installed and that additional radiation be provided for certain rooms which at present are under heated, along with a number of other items. Since there is no night fire in the dormitories at the school, one stove at least is essential. This would enable the school to be kept at a reasonable temperature during the night and it would be easier to bring the rooms up to normal temperature the following day.

Since Indian Affairs has no funds voted for these operations in the present fiscal year, they decided to defer action till next year. When the mechanicals are eventually carried out, the automatic controls on the differential floor heating system should be made to function as they were originally installed to provide economical operation with a minimum of attention.

We will prepare plans and specifications covering the necessary revisions when authorized to do so by Indian Affairs.

Memorandum:

General Inspection Report -
Shingwauk Residential School.

The condition of this school is good. It is evident that the Principal and the staff are actually interested in their pupils and anxious to have them progress as rapidly as possible.

The building is clean and well maintained. Toilets and baths are in good condition. Dormitories are clean and satisfactory. The kitchen and dining-room are well organized. Family style service is used. The sick bay is unusually well appointed.

A good program of extra-curricular activities is carried on. There are teams entered in leagues with Sault Ste. Marie schools and other juvenile teams. There are twenty graduates now living in the school and attending Sault High School and Technical Schools. Several of these girls are interested in normal school and Nurses' Training. There are Boy Scouts, Girl Guides and a Student Council has been started. The Manual Training Instructor seems very capable and is anxious to carry out Departmental policy with regard to vocational training.

RECOMMENDATIONS:

1. That the necessary repairs to the heating system be carried out during the 1948-49 fiscal year.
2. That consideration be given to the construction of a farm house during the 1949-50 fiscal year.
3. That the purchase of more land be investigated.
4. That a gym and Manual Training shop be included.
in our 1950-51 building program.

5. That paint be provided for the dormitories.
6. That screens be provided for the playground windows.
7. That the tuition grant for High School students be raised to $75.00 a month as of April 1, 1948.

You will please find enclosed letter received from the Provincial Department of Labour which is self-explanatory regarding the steel fire escape on the east end of the Shingwauk Indian Residential School.

Subject: Electric wiring in Out-Buildings at Shingwauk Residential School.

Dear Sir:

We have recently been consulted by the Greenwood Electric in connection with some additions to be made to the existing wiring in the above noted buildings. We have since made an inspection of the wiring and would advise you that we find the same to be in a most hazardous condition. The concealed wiring in the main building is installed in sub standard installation with the exception of the added outlet in the hay mow, and separate fusing should be installed on each circuit by the installation of a standard panel. The wiring in the chicken coops and root house is in a very dangerous condition and requires to be entirely rewired. The entire yard overhead wiring is in a very bad condition and should be entirely replaced.

The separate pole type service which supplies current to the out buildings also supplies the Bishop Faquier Chapel and also the engineer's house on Queen St. We find the original wood moulding type of wiring in the chapel with sub standard wiring added and the branch circuit cutouts in a defective condition and fuses plugged with copper pennies. The engineer's house is entirely wired with sub standard wiring protected by an obsolete type main switch supported only by the wiring connected throughout.

In view of the very great fire hazard which the continued use of this wiring creates in these buildings, we would ask you to bring this matter to the attention of the proper authority and to have replacements made where necessary.
We trust that this matter will receive your most earnest consideration and attention,

Yours truly,

V. B. Bizley,
District Electrical Inspector.

Dear Colonel Neary:

Departmental Estimates 1948-49
Shingwauk Indian School, Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.

Early in April, 1948, you advised me that the following funds are provided in your 1948-49 Departmental Estimates for services at Shingwauk School:

Plumbing repairs $5,000.00
Refrigeration 800.00

On checking our submission of 18th October, 1947, of services for inclusion in your 1948-49 Estimates, I cannot find any reference to refrigeration, the services requested being

(a) Improvements to Heating System including installation of a stoker

(b) House for Farm Instructor

(c) Provision of Mammal Training Shop

Perhaps the refrigeration was included on the recommendation of your local Agent but the new Principal reports that the existing electric refrigerator seems to be functioning satisfactorily.

The Principal advises me that your local Agent has informed him that three bids for plumbing have gone forward to you but no contract as yet been awarded. As these repairs on which bids were submitted include installation of radiators in classrooms and necessitate excavation of a considerable length of floor or basement passages, it will be appreciated if the contract can be awarded soon so that as much of the work as possible will be done before the children return and so that it will be completed before cold weather sets in.

p.t.o.
In our submission of 18th October, 1947, we mentioned in regard to the heating system that "so far the only work carried out has been the overhaul and repair of the vacuum pump by the Dunham people". This had been reported to us on 3rd October, 1947, by the then Principal. However, the present Principal reports as follows under date of 24th August, 1948:

"Last fall our Dunham vacuum pump was sent away to the C. A. Dunham Co., Toronto, for repairs and, later, a representative of the firm came here to re-install it and to check the Dunham Vacuum Heating System, which was installed when the school was built to facilitate the flow of steam by drawing off condensed steam. This representative said that the system could not be put into proper working order as the manufacturers no longer carried the essential repair parts. He also stated that he was going to report adversely upon the system direct to the Indian Affairs Branch in Ottawa. Since that time the whole differential vacuum heating system has become useless. Mr. Hayes reports that he can run the pump motor all day without creating an inch of vacuum. If the manufacturer's representative could give no assurance of restoring the apparatus to working order then, obviously, the school must be provided with a satisfactory replacement. Otherwise there will be constant complaints of cold classrooms, etc. this winter. This matter is urgent and I have requested the Department through their local Agent to give the problem due attention with a view to renovation this fall."

May this matter be given attention at an early date, please, as it is obvious that this heating system cannot function properly unless the vacuum return system is in good working order.

Yours truly,

Dear Colonel Neary:

Departmental Estimates, 1949-50
Shingwauk Anglican Indian Residential School, Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.

It will be appreciated if you will make provision in your 1949-50 Departmental Estimates for the following services required at the above-named school. These services are listed in order of urgency:

(a) Coal Cellar

Three different varieties of fuel are needed at this school - lump coal, stoker coal and coke. The capacity of the existing coal cellar is only about 20 tons with the result that fuel can be procured and stored in relatively small quantities which is an expensive method. Besides, the existing cellar is not subdivided into bins for the different varieties of fuel.

A second coal cellar, with capacity of at least 1 earload (40 to 50 tons) adjacent to the present cellar and having a similar cover of reinforced concrete, is urgently required.

(b) Floor coverings in dormitories

The concrete floors of the dormitories on the top storey are badly worn in places and require covering with either mastic tiling or battleship linoleum. The larger dormitory has an area of approximately 1,650 square feet and the smaller dormitory on the boys' side (which needs attention the more urgently of the two) approximately 1,175 square feet.

Estimates obtained from the Northern Tile & Flooring Company, Sault Ste. Marie, show the cost of covering these floors with mastic tiles (combination of A, B and C colours) as

| Larger Dormitory | $672.00 |
| Smaller         | 468.00 |

p.t.o.
The price quoted locally for battleship linoleum and cement (materials alone) is $27.50 per 100 square feet or about $450 for the larger and $323 for the smaller, plus labour for laying.

(c) Manual Training Workshop

A new manual training workshop, or combined workshop and gymnasium, is urgently needed as the present quarters will barely accommodate 6 pupils. The Principal reports that Mr. Doucet had in mind procuring a section of a hangar, 30' x 40' for this purpose.

(d) Surfacing of Yard

The gravel-covered yard lying in the north-west angle of the school building, with an area of about 3,000 square feet, requires hard-surfacing with asphalt or concrete. Snow accumulates in this area and thaws only gradually in the spring because of the northern exposure; in consequence, the approaches to the boys' playroom and basement passage remain dirty for weeks making it impossible to keep the interior in a suitably clean condition.

(e) Painting of Dormitories

The dormitories require painting. The estimated value of the paint needed is $100.00.

(f) Bread-slicing machine

The provision of a bread-slicing machine (115 volt A.C.) has been recommended by the Nutrition Branch, Department of Health and Welfare, as a necessary labour-saving device in a school of this size.

In submitting the foregoing, the Principal has emphasized the urgent need of repairs to the water supply and heating systems, including the vacuum system, before winter sets in this year. I note from your letter 13-0-5[2.1] of 3rd September, 1948, that you are giving attention to these matters.

Yours truly,

Henry G. Cook
Superintendent

Dear Sir:

Re Dunham Vacuum Heating System

I should be obliged if you would direct the attention of The Department to the unsatisfactory condition of our Dunham vacuum pump and heating system in general in order that necessary repairs or replacement may be effected before the steam heating system is put into operation again.

I understand that when the representative of The C. A. Dunham Co., Toronto was here about October last year to re-install the pump and check the vacuum heating system he reported to our engineer and the principal that it was impossible nowadays to get repair parts necessary to make the system operate satisfactorily and was by no means optimistic about the success of the partial repairs which had been made by the manufacturers. He also stated that he was going to submit an unsatisfactory report upon the condition of the system to the Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Our engineer says that it is possible now to run the pump motor all day without getting any appreciable reading on the vacuum gauge, whereas, formerly, it would soon register nine inches and retain a vacuum and the necessary pressure for a number of hours. In other words, the vacuum pump and system is no longer doing the work for which it was installed, namely, to drain the return pipes of condensed steam and, thus, to assist the circulation of live steam throughout the heating system.

Mr. Taylor, representative of The C. A. Dunham Co., is reported to have said that his firm no longer manufactures the type of vacuum system we have installed and that repairs cannot be effected to it.

Now that we are expecting repairs to our domestic hot and cold water supply installations I should be much obliged if you would recommend to The Department that our vacuum pump and heating system be renovated. The need is urgent.

Yours faithfully,

Principal

I wish to acknowledge your letter of Sept. 13th, 1948, file 13-0-5 (E.1), attaching a list of requests from the Superintendent of the M.S.C.C. for inclusion in the 1949-50 estimates for the Shingwauk Residential School.

1. Coal Cellar

The present coal cellar is too small and when a stoker is installed there will be no room for the stoker coal. I recommend that the present cellar either be enlarged or an additional cellar be built as soon as possible.

2. Floor Coverings in Dormitories

The concrete floors of the dormitories in this school are worn and cracked, presenting a very poor appearance. The floors are not up to the standard of the rest of the school and to have them covered with either mastic tiling or battleship linoleum would improve the appearance of the dormitories immensely, as well as making it easier to keep them clean. There are six dormitories and I would recommend that this work be done progressively, two dormitories covered a year until the six are completed.

3. Manual Training Workshop

A manual training workshop is needed as the present room used for this purpose is too small. Mr. Doucet has reported on this matter and suggested that perhaps an army hut could be obtained for this purpose.

There is a large barn at this school in good condition. Only about half of it is now in use. I would suggest that consideration be given to turning the other half into a manual training workshop.

Cont'd...........
4. Surfacing of Yard

Surfacing a portion of the yard would improve conditions in this area for reasons stated by the Principal of the school. However, it is something that does not have to be done right away, but would be an improvement if money were available for this purpose.

5. Painting

The walls of the dormitories require painting and this should be done next year as well as re-plastering broken parts of the wall. The estimated value of paint needed is $100.00 and I would also allow $75.00 for patching the plaster.

6. Bread-slicing Machine

A labour-saving device which should be supplied if money is available.

Superintendent, Indian Agency,

Re: Vacuum pump
Shingwauk Residential School.

On a recent visit to the Sault Ste. Marie agency the condition of the above pump was drawn to my attention; it is part of the low pressure steam heating system and was inspected about a month ago by Mr. Hargraves of the Engineering Branch.

The pump is not working; consequently the steam does not circulate, one part of the building is terribly hot and in the class rooms the temperature is around 55 degrees; with colder weather this will drop much lower, both the teachers and the pupils are complaining of getting colds at the present time.

A new stoker is being installed at the present time, but it will not help unless the pump is working, and a lot of fuel is being wasted trying to get heat into the class rooms.

I would recommend that after immediate consultation with Mr. Hargraves, that the company that installed the pump be asked to send someone familiar with their installation to the school to have it put in shape, apparently the last man they sent did not know enough about them and left it in the present condition.

F. Matters
Regional Supervisor.

"Alterations to domestic hot and cold water installations and to the heating system

Work commenced on this about a month ago, but progress is slow. There is difficulty in getting material - certain copper pipe fittings, radiators, etc. The automatic stoker is overdue.

After Mr. F. Matters paid a visit to the school about two weeks ago our local Indian Superintendent, Mr. R. G. F. Laurence, informed me that the former had been in communication (per 'phone) with Indian Affairs, Ottawa, who stated that certain negotiations with the Dunham Co., Toronto, had been completed whereby repairs to our school vacuum heating system would be undertaken. Here, absolutely nothing has been done and in cold spells, there are the old complaints of cold classrooms and uneven heating. Miss Waterman, who is well acquainted with regulations concerning temperature in Ontario schools, complained just before the visit of the Regional Supervisor above-named, of suffering much from stiffness through teaching in a cold room (55 degrees) and indicated that she would not be able to stand such conditions. Mr. Hayes was doing his best, pending alterations, but, if Dunham's don't get into action, we can look forward to burning a good deal of coal without getting efficient heating."

It is suggested that, in the interest of the health of the pupils and staff, the importance of early action be impressed on the Dunham Company.

Yours truly,

Memorandum

Re: Shingwauk Indian Residential School,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario.

With reference to our telephone conversation of today's date regarding instructions for operating the heating plant at the above, you are advised as follows:

Originally, controls were installed on the above heating system to provide for what is known as a differential system of steam heating. Due to depreciation through normal wear and tear, replacement parts required for certain control items are not necessary if the system is to function as originally intended. It has been established that such replacement parts can no longer be obtained for these controls, and that new items of a more up-to-date design would have to be provided.

Since the school is not in the class of a commercial institution, it is highly questionable whether or not controls of this nature should be installed, having in mind that care and maintenance of a high degree of efficiency can not be expected.

It is recommended therefore, that the system be run under pressure. The motorized valve and the manual selector switch still function and the following directions for operating this system should be followed:

1. Open motorized valve to "Full Open" position using manual control knob at control panel;
2. Run pump on "Vacuum Setting" during the daytime;
3. Run pump on "Float Setting" at night time;
4. Carry steam pressure of 2 lbs. per square inch at the boilers;
5. Set pressuretrol to operate new stoker so as to maintain 2 lbs. per square inch steam pressure.

Upon completion of the work now being carried out, and particularly when the existing main return under the corridor floor in the basement has been replaced, it will likely be found that the vacuum pump, previously serviced, will operate satisfactorily. Operating the system under the above conditions will obviate the use of the room thermostat.

T. S. Mills,
Chief Engineer.

Memorandum

Re: Shingwauk Indian Residential School,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario.

With reference to Major MacKay's memorandum of November 18th, which bears your notation of the 22nd instant, together with a copy of Mr. Cook's letter of November 9th, in connection with the above, you are advised as follows:

As a result of discussions and correspondence with the C.A. Dunham Co., relative to the original controls on the heating system, we are satisfied that through no fault of the Dunham Co., replacement parts can no longer be procured. To replace the old control system with new equipment would entail an amount not considered warrantable in view of the results which could be expected.

Using the main control valve which still may be operated by a manual selector switch in conjunction with the vacuum pump, satisfactory heating results may be realized in a building of this type. The original controls were installed to provide for a complete system of differential steam heating with the object of effecting the ultimate in fuel saving. To obtain the best results from a system of this kind presupposes first class operating staff and efficient maintenance.

We are preparing a letter of instruction in accordance with a verbal telephone discussion with Colonel Neary, outlining the best method of operating the heating system in this school. These instructions are to be forwarded to the Principal by the Indian Affairs Branch.

With reference to the progress being made in connection with the revisions to the domestic hot and cold water system and some alterations to the heating system now being carried out under contract, it is considered that the Contractor is doing all that can be expected of him to complete this work as soon as possible. Most materials are in short supply, and it is on this account that progress is being somewhat retarded.

There is no reason however, why the school should suffer from lack of heat during the time that these operations are being carried out as most of the work now under way is in connection with the domestic hot and cold water system.

Chief Engineer,

MEMORANDUM

Ottawa, December 27, 1948.

Re: Shingwauk Indian Residential School,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario.

In connection with Major Mackay's memorandum of December 18th bearing your notation of the 21st instant, together with copies of letters from Principal D.C. Wickenden, with reference to the above, you are advised as follows:

In his letter to the Superintendent of Indian School Administration, Principal Wickenden outlines a progress report of the work now being carried out at the above. The amount of work executed to date and the results, are in our opinion, satisfactory. The system cannot be expected to function efficiently in all its phases until the installation has been completed. The shortage of materials is holding up the work and the contractor cannot be held responsible for this condition, as it is in his own interests to proceed with all the means at his command, and we are satisfied that he is doing so.

Commenting on the Principal's letter to Indian Superintendent Laurence, it can be stated that additional covering on the boilers would increase their efficiency. It is pointed out that as a result of inspections carried out at various residential schools, operations necessary to bring the plants up to the highest degree of operating efficiency would result in much larger sums of money being made necessary that it is reasonable to ask for.

Our studied recommendations have been made on the basis of providing the essential and fundamental repairs and revisions needed to provide comfort and overall efficiency in the various schools at a cost considered justified.

With this in mind, we felt that additional covering for these boilers was not warranted. The contract price for the work outlined on our plans and specifications was considerably in excess of our original estimate, due to sharp rises in materials and labour which had taken place since the time our original request for action was submitted in April, 1947, and the letting of the contract recently. However, should the Indian Affairs Branch wish to have this extra covering added, provided funds are available, we would have no objection.

With reference to the economical heating of domestic hot water for summer service, you are advised that our original intention was to run one of the heating boilers to provide steam for this purpose through the new indirect automatically controlled water heater now being installed as part of the contract. The present jacket heater in addition to being greatly undersized, is now reported to be in poor condition.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Director,
Indian Affairs Branch.

For your information.

We do not consider it advisable to repair or replace this jacket heater as its use in connection with the large domestic hot water storage tank would not be as satisfactory or as efficient as using one of the heating boilers.

Since the hot water demand decreases in the summertime on account of the pupils being away on leave, and since there is but one domestic hot water storage tank, it is considered that with the type of plant in the above school, the use of one of the heating boilers for providing domestic hot water in the summertime can be justified. It is felt that the Principal should be advised to this effect.

Dear Col. Neary:

Last month the Department approved an expenditure of $500.00 for the purpose of clearing bushland for cultivation on the northern limits of the school property. This work was undertaken by L.R. Brown & Co. of Sault Ste. Marie, who began bulldozing operations early this month. Unfortunately the land proved to be too wet for the clearing to be completed and it is not likely that a tractor will be able to operate successfully until the summer of next year, when the land should be comparatively dry. It is estimated that an area of approximately 41 acres has been cleared with the brush piled in windrows at a cost of $35.00 per acre. This means that the sum authorized for expenditure will not be appropriated in toto during the current fiscal year, and I am writing now to enquire whether you would favorably consider the diversion of the balance of the $600.00 authorized, i.e., $325.00 more or less, for expenditure upon a service which was requested last August for inclusion in the Departmental Estimates for the year 1950-51.

There is a full sized attic in the principal's residence which, a floor area of 32 ft. by 12 ft. This was left unfinished with unlined rafters and studding, and second floor and window trimmings etc. lacking. With such a large space uninsulated a good deal of heat is dissipated in the winter and the whole house is colder than it might be. For an expenditure of roughly $200.00 on flooring, insulating material and ten-test (or similar wallboard) etc. I estimate that this work could be done properly with corresponding saving in fuel and gain in comfort. The labour I will gladly attend myself.

I trust that this request will receive your kind consideration and that you will advise me at your earliest convenience.

In the services desired for the year 1950-51 the completion of land-reclamation will, of course, be requested by substitution.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]
Principal

Temporary appointment of an Inspector of Construction, Sault Ste Marie, Ont.

August 22, 1934

The Department is building a school within the city limits of Sault Ste Marie at a cost of $350,000.

The Commission is requested to arrange for the appointment of an Inspector of Construction at $7 per day for a period of between nine and twelve months.

It has been determined that the Department of Public Works has recently been able to obtain a satisfactory representation in this class at this point for $6 per day in connection with wharf construction. Their standard rate for building construction is 2½ of the cost of the bare buildings.

The Department of Indian Affairs has been interviewed for the purpose of ascertaining their reasons for suggesting the minimum rate provided under Classification. The reasons given are that the recruiting field at Sault Ste Marie is limited, being confined to possibly three or four who might apply, and that in their opinion the rate proposed was the minimum equitable rate and the very least which will assure proper supervision.

As a result of the above findings a telephone enquiry was directed to the Department of Labour which Department advised that as the Department of Public Works had this Spring been furnished with a list of the ratings for this class, enquiry should be directed to them. The Commission was later advised by the Department of Labour that no available figures existed but an effort would be made to obtain the information desired.

As but little inspection work can be done by the regular departmental staff except at prohibitive cost and at the maximum cost under
the rate proposed by the Department will be well within the percentage costs standard in the profession, and the Department of Public Works, the appointment at $7 per day is recommended.

Dear Sir,

During my interview with the Superintendent of Indian Education on the last inst. I directed his attention to the fact that our Society has been obliged to pay yearly since we undertook the administration of the Shingwauk Home the sum of $250 for land rented for the use of this institution, and requested that we be relieved from this expenditure. December 13th, 1928.

I visited the Shingwauk Home on December 4th and 5th.

Additional Land:

There has been previous correspondence with reference to securing additional land. The farm at the school consists of forty-nine (49) acres, of which only about twenty (20) can be cultivated. The Department has been allowing $250 a year to pay rent for a farm situated about two miles from the school.

Mr. Fuller pointed out that this latter farm is very inconvenient for many reasons that will readily suggest themselves.

The property that has been offered to them has an area of forty-nine (49) acres and immediately adjoins the present school property on the side nearest to Sault Ste. Marie. Dear Mr Scott:

With further reference to the matters discussed between us in our interview held on Friday, the 3rd inst., I beg permission to place in writing the following considerations:

I. The proposal for the erection of new buildings for the Shingwauk Home Indian Residential School. My understanding is that, all matters relating to the site of the new buildings, as between the existing general location, or a new location to be chosen on the Garden River Reserve, are left completely open for reconsideration and examination before a final decision is made. In this connection I would suggest that, as in other similar cases, an examination of alternative sites be made by representatives, acting jointly, of the Department and of the Missionary Society. If this suggestion meets with your approval, we should be prepared, at such time as you may desire, to appoint our representatives.

The Bishop of Algoma, in his letter to me, dated December 11th, 1929, states in part, as follows:

"Such members of the Executive (that is the Executive Committee of the Diocese of Algoma) as were available made personally a very thorough examination of the Home, and agree unreservedly with the Deputy Superintendent General that the Shingwauk Home is 'no longer suitable for purposes of an Indian Residential School.'

"The Diocese holds both land and School under a trust dated as long ago as 1875." The terms of this trust, however allow of the disposal of the properties in question.
providing that the sums accruing be invested and the profits used "for the purposes of Indian education in the Shingwauk Home."

The Bishop states further the following reasons in favor of the retention of the present general site:

"The Committee feels strongly that the present site, or the high land at the back of the present school, which forms part of the Shingwauk land, should be retained, and sincerely hopes that the Department will be strongly pressed to abandon the idea of a site on the Garden River Reserve. In support of this opinion, we would advance the following reasons:-

(A) From the present school it is quite easy to take the children who attend Sault Ste Marie Collegiate Institute to and from their school, in a car in summer and in a sleigh in winter, a distance of less than three miles. The children of members of the Staff are able, too, to attend school in the City. If the School were moved to Garden River, it would be almost impossible to do this, as the distance would be at least nine miles and perhaps considerably more. In this connection it should be stated that if the school were removed to the Reserve, which is outside the City limits, the Home would have to pay tuition fees at the Collegiate Institute for the children who attend.

(B) The Bishop Fauquier Memorial Chapel would not be able to be used as a school church. This is a beautiful church, conveniently situated, and both present and past members of the school have a deep affection for it.

(C) The present cemetery would be neglected. In this cemetery lie several great friends and benefactors of the school, such as its first trustee, Bishop Fauquier, the late Archdeacon Gillmor, Mrs Fuller, and Miss McNeill a faithful worker in the school, besides a large number of Indian pupils. It would be a great grief to the old pupils and friends of the school if the cemetery, which is so sacred a place to them, were to be cut off entirely from the care of the school authorities and neglected.

(D) The Garden River Reserve is absolutely cut off from the City in winter. There is only one train a day in each direction which stops at the station, and it is impossible for members of the staff and their friends to go down by one train and up by the other, as the times of arrival and departure are too close together."
There are many people in the City who take a personal interest in the school and go to visit it from time to time, including many who are not members of our Church. This is a very valuable humanizing influence for the pupils and a source of pleasure and inspiration to the staff. To maintain this contact and keep up this interest would be much more difficult, even in summer, if the school were moved to the Reserve.

The Principal feels that it is better for the Indian children not to be too near to the Reserve. His experience has shown him that they are easier to manage when away from the influence of their own people.

The land of the Reserve is not very good for the purposes of the School Farm. The only parts available for the school are of too sandy a character to be useful for agricultural work.

The present site of the Home is almost an ideal one. It is just within the City limits, guaranteeing all City conveniences, such as water, light, etc., and yet it is away from the crowded traffic of the City. It is only a mile from the street cars, and there is a good road, so that the problem of transportation is an easy one. It faces the river, and therefore buildings can never be erected opposite it; and it overlooks Bellevue Park, which will keep it for all time from being crowded out by city buildings.

These reasons appear to us to constitute a well-nigh unanswerable argument in favor of retaining the present site, or at least one upon some part of the land at present belonging to the school, say "the higher ground behind the present site", as suggested in Dr. Westgate's letter to me of January 14th, 1929.

I cannot add much in support of the above strong presentation of consideration in favor of a site for the new buildings on the existing general location, except to say that, from the scenic and publicity standpoint, buildings erected on the rising ground a short distance behind the existing buildings, would occupy a site superior, probably, to any other in the Dominion; in that they would hold a very prominent place, in the view of the Canadian shore, to every passenger on every steamer passing up or down the River.

Dear Sir:

In the list of requirements for the Shingwauk Home submitted to your Department this autumn, and to be provided during the fiscal year 1931, (see page 4 h. of the list) additional land was included, and your attention directed to my letter of Oct. 17th, 1929, with regard to a parcel of 49 acres located alongside the present school property.

Enclosed herewith is a copy of a letter received by the Principal of the Shingwauk Home dealing further with this question and making reference to the terms on which a further parcel of 57 acres could also be purchased for the use of the school.

When forwarding the enclosed letter to me, the Principal wrote, in part, as follows:

"I may say that owing to the dry season, our grain crop was almost a failure, and therefore the harvest was very poor. I may also say that owing to the fact that our farm land is located two miles away from the Shingwauk Home, it is almost impossible to do any successful farming of grain. The land does not get the attention it should, and consequently it is in a very dirty and impoverished state.

A great deal of time and labour was spent on the land during last Spring and Summer, but so much time is wasted on the road, and it is impossible to do much hauling on account of the bad road, that most of the work done and time spent was of very little avail.

I would urgently recommend that the properties adjoining the..."
school lands, and belonging to Laird, and Rowland, comprising nearly one hundred acres of very good land, be purchased for the Shingwauk Home. This matter has been under consideration now for a number of years. The need is just as urgent as it ever was. In fact, now that our pupilage is increased, and future prospects of a further increase appear, the need seems to me to be the more urgent.

For your information, I enclose herewith a letter received sometime ago in this connection, giving the details regarding the price of the land. I am of the opinion that the Rowland land could be bought for considerably less than is quoted in the enclosed letter.

The potato crop generally was rather a failure this year, and generally speaking there was a third of a crop. Garden produce was fairly good considering the land we had to use. I may say that next year our farming activities should be very much more encouraging, as we have practically all our land prepared. Dear Dr. McGill:

In reply to your letter dated the 18th inst., I quote the resolution adopted by the Executive Committee of the Diocese of Algoma, 11th of March 1930, as amended on the 8th of April 1930, as follows:

Moved by Mr F.W. Major,
Seconded by Rev. John Tate,

"That this Executive Committee of the Diocese of Algoma, having considered the proposal to transfer the land in connection with the Shingwauk Home (with the exception of the site of the Chapel and the Cemetery) to the Department of Indian Affairs, lays down the following as the principle to which they feel committed by the terms of the trust under which the property is now held by the Synod of Algoma.

"The essential element in such transfer is the preservation and continuance of the terms of the present trust held by the Diocese of Algoma; which provide that the properties, or their proceeds if sold, must be applied for all time to the purposes of Indian Residential School education, with complete liberty regarding religious instruction under the administration and control of the Church of England in Canada.

"The Executive Committee approves of the transfer to the Department of the said land, with the exceptions noted, for the erection thereon by the Department of an Indian Residential School to replace the present Shingwauk Home, upon conditions which will embody in the terms of transfer the requirements of the trust; it being specified that should the Department cease to use the property in accordance with these terms, then the land shall, at that time, be purchased by the Department at a current valuation to be agreed upon by the Department and the Executive Committee of the Diocese of Algoma."
"The Department shall purchase any building or buildings which may continue in use in connection with the new school. All other buildings taken over, including the main building of the existing school, shall be wrecked and removed by the Department, which shall also fill in the excavation.

"The Department shall further supplement the land transferred by the purchase or rental of such additional land as may be necessary to provide a farm sufficient in size to meet the requirements of the new school in the way of farm produce, milk, eggs, etc." Carried.

I assume that the above resolution represents still the mind of the Authorities of the diocese of Algoma, owner of the property. I am therefore forwarding a copy of your letter, together with copy of this reply, to the Right Reverend Rockborough R. Smith, Lord Bishop of Algoma, "Bishophurst", Sault Ste Marie, Ont.

I am leaving in a few days for a month's absence in Western Canada, and suggest that you conduct any further correspondence required, directly with the Bishop of Algoma.

We are all very pleased that the Shingwauk Home is now to be provided with the new buildings so urgently needed for so long a time.

Believe me,

Dear Sir,

I enclose herewith a plan which I am submitting to you for your consideration. The part surrounded by the heavy red line contains 200 acres, more or less. This land is just three quarters of a mile from our school property and borders on the city limits. It is fairly good land, which has been a very heavy forest before timber was taken off. It is now, more or less, covered with small bush. The price per acre is eighteen dollars, which is two dollars less than they originally asked for it. I am informed that the land is free of any mortgage etc., and that a clear title can be had. I do not know of any more desirable land to be bought within reasonable distance, and would recommend that the site described by the enclosed plan be bought to supplement our present farm.

Of course, such a piece of land will require a great deal of hard work in order to make a farm of it. It will have to be fenced first of all, then gradually cleared of bush, and broken up. I think if we reckon on clearing and breaking up fifty acres each year, and reckon on spending one thousand dollars each year for this purpose, we should have a good productive farm at the end of three or four years.

If the Department decides to buy this land for us, I would like to get at the fencing as soon as possible, and would recommend that the fencing be done this fall in the event of your purchasing the land.

I have your letter of the third instant, enclosing a communication which you received from the Principal of the Shingwauk Indian Residential School, in which he requests that the necessary fencing and cedar posts be supplied to erect a fence in front of the school property, to prevent the cattle from getting into the garden and other places.

In reply I have to say the Department will approve of an expenditure, which must not exceed the sum of $25.00, in the purchase of the necessary fencing and posts. You should arrange for the purchase from firms on the approved list, obtaining accounts, in triplicate, covering the cost. These accounts, you should attach to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward for payment. It is understood that the school authorities will do the work of erecting the fence, without cost to the Department. This fence should be erected before the extremely cold weather sets in.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

G. H. Sims, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.

Dear Mr Sims:

I am writing you regarding the grounds in front of the building, and particularly that part where the old building stood. I am very anxious, this Spring to get it looking decent. We did quite a lot to it, last year, in getting out stones and leveling, through the help the Department gave us, but there remains a lot of heavy work to be done, and we have not the boys to do this heavy work. We do a lot of work with them, but I am quite sure the Department would not want them over worked, as I feel sure they would be if we depend on them alone.

The Synod of the Dioceses of Algoma meets in the Soo during the month of June, and they are all invited here to lunch. I would like to have the grounds in good order for that time.

Will you kindly place this matter before the Department, as a very urgent one. I estimate that $300.00 would complete the work of clearing, cleaning, leveling, and seeding. I would also like to see a good flag pole in front, and this would cost another $50.00

We are working at it now, but we cannot make a great deal of headway under the circumstances, and I would be very glad if you would take this matter up as soon as possible.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Principal.

Sir:

This letter speaks for itself, and there is little I can add to it, beyond saying I have been down to inspect the work, and would recommend that Mr. Hives request be granted if at all possible. I may say that they have done wonderfully well with the improving of the front of the building, but it is very heavy work and requires a lot of fill where the old building stood in order to give it a proper appearance.

If possible, I would recommend that Mr. Hives request be granted.

Dear Sir:

Reply to your letter of the 1st inst. (Letter No. 13-0-9) I beg to say that the circumstances which necessitated our renting Mrs Wilcox' land for hay meadow were as follows:

The Shingwank Home has no hay land, and very little pasture for the cows. After the completion of the new building, any appropriation was made by the Department for the purpose of buying land for the school. At that time, no land suitable was available, and the appropriation lapsed. In the meantime the Rankin Estate, which the school had rented for a number of years was subdivided and sold to small owners. We had to look for pasture and hay meadow elsewhere. The late Dr. McCaig had a piece of suitable land about ten miles away from the school, and although distance made it very inconvenient in many ways, yet it was the only hay meadow available, and we procured our hay from there for a number of years. Last year, the land was found to be so impoverished from the constant harvesting, that Dr. McCaig decided to have half of it broken up, and charge us with half the rental, heretofore paid. This matter was not definitely settled with the late Doctor, for illness and death intervened.

It was very necessary that the school should have sufficient hay, and the only available meadow was that of Mrs Wilcox. I thought it best to rent this land, and was certainly under the impression that the combined rental of lands would not exceed very much if any what I paid other years. I am sorry this matter was not settled before I left, for I think it should have been in quite a satisfactory way. Certainly the school required the hay in order to feed the cows for the Winter.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Mr. Hives,

With reference to the curtains for the new Shingwauk Indian Residential School Miss Walton has advised that it is your intention to have some of the curtains made with a frill across the top and the curtains hanging down the sides. I am of the opinion, owing to the construction of the windows, that this would not be a suitable arrangement. I believe it would much improve the appearance of the rooms if the curtains were made on rods fastened to the window sash in such a manner that they would not project beyond the window openings, and I would ask you to have them made in this way.

For the Reception Room, Office and Staff Sitting Rooms you may purchase suitable side curtains. These will have to be hung from a rod placed over the top of the window opening, in order to allow the side curtains to project past the window. Special rods are made for this purpose. You may place the order for the side curtains with either Astin's or the Soo Jobbing Co.

Miss Walton has drawn my attention to the fact that you did not include in your list of requirements the rods for the window curtains. You may order these from either the hardware firms who were asked to tender on the hardware or from Astin's or Soo Jobbing Co.

With regard to the Sewing Machines the Purchasing Branch are today placing an order for one electric and two treadle Singer Sewing Machines.

With reference to the gymnasium mattresses you may place an order with the Soo Outfitting Co., who I understand quoted you a price of 90 cents per square foot, for two mattresses 8 x 6 feet.

Yours very truly,

R. Gurney Orr.

Dear Mr Orr:

There are several things I would like to ask you. First, is it safe for me to recommend that the official opening take place on Sept. 4th. I would like if possible, not to leave it any later than we can help, on account of the weather.

We have made a very nice looking front to the grounds, but there is much to be done yet. If you have the funds to spare, I would like two hundred dollars more to spend on it. This would, I believe finish the job, and I feel sure you would be satisfied with it.

Then we need some fencing around for playground boundaries. This, I estimate, would cost eighty dollars. We could do the work ourselves.

In regard to the lumber mills here, I may say that both firms, who have tendered, are good reliable firms. The Bee Lumber have better equipment in the way of drying kilns and machinery, and on that account would do probably a neater and quicker job.

I think Miss Waltam has spoken to you about kitchen ranges. It certainly would be a great thing if we could have the electric range for the kitchen, but don't worry about it if you think it too extravagant.

Thanks for your letter regarding curtain material etc. I will take care of it.

Yours faithfully,

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

Mr. Fuller, Principal of the Shingwauk Home, states that there is a boy about twelve years old who shows strong symptoms of tuberculosis. His whole family, including his father and mother, three brothers and a sister, have died from this disease.

I think this boy would be too young to send to a sanitarium and the expense of keeping him there would be about $10.00 a week. I can vouch for it that he will receive every care and attention at the school and I think he would probably be better there than anywhere else, as he would be most unhappy if he were sent to a sanitarium. I think if the boy were relieved of school work and allowed to be in the open air as much as possible with more nourishing food than the ordinary school bill of fare calls for he might benefit by it and I would suggest that Mr. Fuller be allowed something additional for his maintenance, if he is willing to keep the boy. His presence there would be no menace to the other pupils, as he could be easily isolated.

Dear Sir:

One of the pupils in our school who has been attending High School for the past term, and who, with others has had a bad cold for some time, still retains a very bad cough, and refuses to build up although we are doing for him all we can. We have been hoping that when his cold left him he would recover his normal condition, but we are becoming alarmed about him, and I am writing to you for your advice.

It would seem best to send him at once to some Hospital where he would be treated especially for his trouble, which we believe is tubercular. Should he be taken to a local hospital, he would only receive the same treatment that we are giving him here, and there would be the extra expense, and no advantage.

The boy's name is Roy Richards. He has no home, and no relations to care for him. He came from away north of Fort William, and his parents are dead. He has an Aunt living in Fort William, who at times has sent clothes for him, but she has always warned us not to write to her regarding Roy because her husband would not like to know that she had any thing to do with this boy. Roy's Uncle, Rev. Edward Richards, died two years ago. He was a missionary in the North, and we had hopes that we could lead Roy on so that some day he could take a place, and carry on the work his Uncle was so interested in.

Roy is up, and out every day, and we will do all we can for him, but we would like to have your advice and permission to place him where he will get every chance there is for him.

Nearly all of the pupils in the Home contracted heavy colds during the past winter, even the staff did not escape, but all but Roy are well again, for which we are very thankful.

Obediently yours,

[Signature]

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 22nd instant, reporting on the case of Roy Richards, a pupil of the Shingwauk Home, whom you believe to be in the first stages of tuberculosis, and requesting that he be placed in a hospital for the special treatment required in his case.

In reply I beg to say that, before any action can be taken, it will be necessary to have this boy examined by a doctor, who should furnish you with a full report regarding his present state of health and a recommendation as to what he would advise be done to give the treatment required. You may request Dr. A. S. McCaig, Sault Ste. Marie, to examine the boy, and you should forward his report and recommendation to the Department. When this is received, consideration will be given to the question of arranging for this boy's treatment.

Dear Sir:

Enclosed please find a statement from Dr. Duncan for X-Ray service given Ada Esquimaux on the evening of June 14th.

You may know more about this than I do, but I think the charge is high.

The case was like this. I had just come from Town, and some one ran to meet me to tell me that Ada had just swallowed a pin, and that it was stuck in her throat, out of reach to allow of us getting it out, and we at once took her up to Dr. McCallum. He referred us to Dr. Hamilton, and he took us to the general Hospital for the X-Ray. Dr. Hamilton, nor Dr. Duncan could locate the pin, and we came to the conclusion that it had either come up while she was coughing at a wash bowl, or had passed down into her stomach. We watched her for a time and there was no bad effects.

I hope you are feeling well.

MEMORANDUM

Mr. Paget.

In November, 1921, the Ontario Provincial Board of Health drew to our attention the deplorable conditions in Indian homes at Stevenson, Tilbury East Township. Dr. Scott directed Mr. Abraham to make an inspection and report. Mr. Abraham reported that the Indians claim to be Pottawatamie, of the same group as Chief Caldwell. The Deputy directed that some of the children be placed in a residential school.

One of these Indians, Olive Peters, was sent to the Shingwauk Home, Sault Ste. Marie. She is now 16 years of age, and is far from well. She has always had bad glands on her neck. The Principal reports that she has been ill for a short time this winter "but is up and down, some days feeling better, and then in bed not so well".

She should be discharged from the school, and, I believe, the only suitable place for her is a hospital. Can arrangements be made?

In connection with future dental service for the pupils of your school, I have to inform you that the Department's practice is to insist on only the necessary extractions and inexpensive fillings. In the case of temporary teeth, only extractions can be allowed. The fee set by this department is $1.00 per amalgam filling and 25¢ per extraction when local anesthesia is necessary in extraction. $1.00 is allowed for the first tooth in the case of each patient and 25¢ for each additional tooth. It is considered that it should not be necessary to use local anesthesia as frequently as appears to have been done, as per charges for this service in the account above referred to.

The amounts for dental attention at this school have been quite large during the past year, and, in future, only the more urgent cases among the pupils should have this work done. The Department will rely on you to see that all cost for dental service is kept as low as possible and that all work carried out is absolutely necessary.

The Department's practice is to allow only necessary extractions and inexpensive fillings. In the case of temporary teeth, only extractions can be allowed. The fees set by this Department where there are several children requiring attention, $1.00 per amalgam filling and 25¢ per extraction. When local anaesthesia is necessary when extracting, $1.00 is allowed for the first tooth in the case of each patient and 25¢ for each additional tooth. Please see Dr. Goodfellow at your convenience, and, if he accepts the Department's proposal, you may arrange to have him perform the dental work recommended by the medical officer of the school as being really necessary for the health of the pupils. Accounts should be in duplicate and should show the name of each pupil and the number of fillings and extractions. The accounts should be certified by you and forwarded to the Department for payment.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,

Dear Sir:

I regret to have to report to you the death of one of our pupils, No. 362 Lawrence Buszowski, one of our newest pupils who came from Birch Island. This boy was instantly killed this morning.

Every morning the boys are lined up, and I personally detail them to their work etc. This morning I lined them up as usual, and on account of the Christmas holidays coming on, after I had given the older boys their necessary chore duties, I told about twenty smaller boys, deceased being one, to go to the toboggan slide and have a good time. I may say that I have had good slides made for them. Instead of going, deceased thought he should help some bigger boys to pile wood in the wood shed.

In the wood shed is the end of a pulley shaft which operates the laundry machinery. Today being Monday, and laundry day, the shaft was turning. Nobody knows just what happened, as he was by himself. The shaft is about seven feet from the ground, but wood had been piled up so that he could reach it, and somehow his clothing caught on the shaft, and he was whirled around and death was instantaneous.

I wired the boy's mother immediately after the accident, and received a wire from her asking that the body be sent to her. I therefore wired you asking for sanction to do so.

Coming as it does at this season, this terrible fatality has cast a cloud over our Christmas. I feel it is an accident that none of us could possibly have foreseen, but just a result of a very clumsy arrangement of machinery.

Your obedient servant,

September 17th, 1931.

Dear Mr. Sims,

I have been asked to reply to your letter of September 9th enclosing the requisition of Mr. Hives for a sanitary spray. I have also been asked not to recommend anything that would cost too much money.

We know that the floors at the school are not very good and appreciate the reason for wanting an apparatus of this kind. I am allowed to authorize the purchase of a suitable spraying apparatus or gun, but I recommend one of the two following solutions for use in it, as they are both very cheap and quite suitable:

1. Lysol, I.D., 1 tablespoon to 1 gallon of water.

2. Chloride of Lime - 1 pound, Washing Soda - 1½ pounds, water - 10 gallons.

Make a smooth paste of the Chloride of Lime in a suitable quantity of water. Dissolve the Washing Soda and add the solution to the Chloride of Lime. Let stand over-night and strain through a cloth or other strainer. Add water to make 10 gallons. This solution is very effective and will help to bleach the floors white. It will also bleach everything else it touches and should be applied with a mop rather than with the bare hands. It will corrode metal and should not be used in a metal operating gun. I recommend this solution on the ground of efficiency and cheapness.

The Department will supply the materials in either case; but would like to be consulted before any large expenditure is made for apparatus.

Yours truly,

G.H. Sims, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.

E.L. Stone, M.B.,
Director of Medical Services
